verses.latin: Post mortem Josue, consuluerunt filii Israel Dominum, dicentes: Quis ascendet ante nos contra Chananaeum, et erit dux belli?
verses.english: After the death of Joshua, the sons of Israel consulted the Lord, asking: 'Who among us will go up first against the Canaanites, and be the leader of the war?'

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus: Judas ascendet: ecce tradidi terram in manu ejus.
verses.english: And the Lord said: 'Judah will go up; behold, I have given the land into his power.'

verses.latin: Et ait Judas Simeoni fratri suo: Ascende mecum in sortem meam, et pugna contra Chananaeum, ut et ego pergam tecum in sortem tuam. Et abiit cum eo Simeon.
verses.english: And Judah said to Simeon, his brother: 'Come with me into my allotted territory, and fight against the Canaanites, so that I also may go with you into your allotted territory and help you.' And Simeon went with him.

verses.latin: Ascenditque Judas, et tradidit Dominus Chananaeum, et Pherezaeum in manus eorum: et percusserunt in Bezec decem millia virorum.
verses.english: So Judah went up, and the Lord gave the Canaanites and the Perizzites into their power. And they struck down ten thousand men in Bezek.

verses.latin: Inveneruntque Adonibezec in Bezec, et pugnaverunt contra eum, et percusserunt Chananaeum, et Pherezaeum.
verses.english: And they found Adoni-Bezek in Bezek, and fought against him, and struck down the Canaanites and the Perizzites who were with him.

verses.latin: Fugit autem Adonibezec, quem persecuti comprehenderunt, caesis summitatibus manuum ejus, et pedum.
verses.english: But Adoni-Bezek fled, and they pursued him and captured him. They then cut off the tips of his hands and his feet.

verses.latin: Dixitque Adonibezec: Septuaginta reges, amputatis manuum ac pedum summitatibus, colligebant sub mensa mea ciborum reliquias: sicut feci, ita reddidit mihi Deus. Adduxeruntque eum in Jerusalem, et ibi mortuus est.
verses.english: And Adoni-Bezek said: 'Seventy kings, with the tips of their hands and feet cut off, gathered the scraps of food under my table. As I have done to them, so God has now repaid me.' Then they brought him to Jerusalem, and he died there.

verses.latin: Oppugnantes ergo filii Juda Jerusalem ceperunt, et percusserunt in ore gladii, quicquid in ea repererant, succensisque igni civitatis moenibus.
verses.english: The sons of Judah then attacked Jerusalem and captured it. They put to the sword all they found in it, and then burned the city walls with fire.

verses.latin: Et post haec descenderunt ut pugnarent contra Chananaeum, qui habitabat in montanis, et ad meridiem, et in campestribus.
verses.english: And after these things, they went down to fight against the Canaanites who lived in the mountainous region, and to the south, and in the lowlands.

verses.latin: Pergensque Judas contra Chananaeum, qui habitabat in Hebron (cujus nomen antiquitus Carath Arbe) percussit Sesai, et Ahiman, et Tholmai.
verses.english: Judah then went against the Canaanites who lived in Hebron (which was anciently called Kirjath-Arba), and struck down Sheshai, and Ahiman, and Talmai.

verses.latin: Atque inde profectus abiit ad habitatores Dabir, cujus nomen vetus erat Cariath Sepher, id est, civitas litterarum.
verses.english: And from there he proceeded to the inhabitants of Debir, whose ancient name was Kirjath-Sepher, which means 'the city of books'.

verses.latin: Dixitque Caleb: Qui percusserit Cariath Sepher, et ceperit eam, dabo ei Achsa filiam meam uxorem.
verses.english: And Caleb said: 'Whoever strikes down Kirjath-Sepher and captures it, I will give him Achsah, my daughter, as his wife.'

verses.latin: Cepitque eam Othoniel filius Cenez, frater Caleb minor: deditque ei Achsa filiam suam uxorem.
verses.english: And Othniel, the son of Kenaz, Caleb's younger brother, captured it. So Caleb gave him Achsah, his daughter, as his wife.

verses.latin: Quae cum pergeret, monuit virum suum ut peteret a patre suo agrum. Suspiravitque in asino sedens. Cui Caleb: Quid habes?
verses.english: As she went with Othniel, she urged her husband to ask her father for a field. She then dismounted from her donkey with a sigh of desire. And Caleb asked her: 'What do you want?'

verses.latin: At illa respondit: Da mihi benedictionem: terram arentem dedisti mihi et aquosam quoque tribue. Dedit ergo ei Caleb irriguum superius, et inferius.
verses.english: And she replied: 'Give me a special gift. You have given me dry land; now also grant me springs of water.' So Caleb gave her the upper spring and the lower spring.

verses.latin: Filii autem Cinaei cognati Moysi ascenderunt de civitate palmarum cum filiis Juda in desertum Judae, quod est ad orientalem plagam Arad: et habitaverunt cum eo.
verses.english: Now the children of the Kenite, Moses' relative by marriage, went up from the City of Palms (Jericho) with the sons of Judah into the Wilderness of Judah, which is to the south of Arad, and they lived there with them.

verses.latin: Abiitque Judas cum Simeone fratre suo, et percusserunt Chananaeum, qui habitabat in Sephaath, et interfecerunt eum. Vocatumque est nomen civitatis Horma.
verses.english: Then Judah went with Simeon, his brother, and they struck down the Canaanites who lived in Zephath, and utterly destroyed them. So the name of the city was called Hormah.

verses.latin: Cepitque Judas Gazam cum finibus suis, et Ascalonem, atque Accaron cum finibus suis.
verses.english: Judah also captured Gaza with its territory, and Ashkelon with its territory, and Ekron with its territory.

verses.latin: Fuitque Dominus cum Juda, et percussit montanos: nec potuit delere habitatores vallium, quia falcatis curribus plurimis nitebantur.
verses.english: And the Lord was with Judah, and they drove out the inhabitants of the mountainous region. But they could not drive out the inhabitants of the valleys, because those had many iron chariots with scythes.

verses.latin: Dederuntque Caleb Hebron, sicut dixerat Moyses, qui delevit ex ea tres filios Enac.
verses.english: And they gave Hebron to Caleb, just as Moses had said, and from there he drove out the three sons of Anak.

verses.latin: Jebusaeum autem habitatorem Jerusalem non deleverunt filii Benjamin, et habitavit Jebusaeus cum filiis Benjamin in Jerusalem usque in praesentem diem.
verses.english: But the sons of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites who inhabited Jerusalem, so the Jebusites have lived with the sons of Benjamin in Jerusalem until the present day.

verses.latin: Domus quoque Joseph ascendit in Bethel, et Dominus erat cum eis.
verses.english: The house of Joseph also went up against Bethel, and the Lord was with them.

verses.latin: Nam cum obsiderent civitatem, quae vocabatur Luza, (cujus in veteribus temporibus Bethel nomen erat)
verses.english: For when they were besieging the city that was called Luzah (whose name in ancient times was Bethel),

verses.latin: viderunt hominem egredientem de civitate, et sollicitaverunt eum dicentes: Ostende nobis introitum civitatis, et faciemus tecum misericordiam.
verses.english: they saw a man coming out of the city, and they urged him, saying: 'Show us the entrance to the city, and we will show you mercy.'

verses.latin: Qui cum ostendisset eis, percusserunt urbem in ore gladii: hominem autem illum, et omnem cognationem ejus dimiserunt.
verses.english: And when he showed them, they struck down the city with the edge of the sword. But they let that man and all his relatives go free.

verses.latin: Qui profectus in terram Hetthim aedificavit illic civitatem, vocavitque eam Luzam: quae est nomen ejus usque in praesentem diem.
verses.english: That man then went to the land of the Hittites and built a city there, and called its name Luzah. That is its name to this present day.

verses.latin: Manasses quoque non delevit Bethsan, et Thanac cum viculis suis: et habitatores Dor, et Jeblaam, et Mageddo cum viculis suis: coeperuntque Chananaeus habitare cum eis.
verses.english: Manasseh also did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-Shean and Taanach with their surrounding villages, nor the inhabitants of Dor, Ibleam, and Megiddo with their surrounding villages. So the Canaanites began to live among them.

verses.latin: Postquam autem confortatus est Israel, fecit tributarios Chananaeos, et delere noluit.
verses.english: But after Israel became strong, they made the Canaanites subject to tribute, and were unwilling to drive them out completely.

verses.latin: Ephraim quoque non interfecit Chananaeum, qui habitabat in Gazer, et habitavit Chananaeus cum eo in Gazer.
verses.english: Ephraim also did not kill the Canaanites who lived in Gezer, so the Canaanites lived among them in Gezer.

verses.latin: Zabulon non delevit habitatores Cetron, et Naalol: sed habitavit Chananaeus in medio ejus, factusque est ei tributarius.
verses.english: Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron and Nahalol. Instead, the Canaanites lived among them and became subject to tribute.

verses.latin: Aser quoque non delevit habitatores Accho, et Sidonis, Ahalab, et Achazib, et Helba, et Aphek, et Rohob:
verses.english: Asher also did not drive out the inhabitants of Acco, nor of Sidon, Ahlab, Achzib, Helbah, Aphik, or Rehob.

verses.latin: et habitavit in medio Chananaei habitatoris terrae, nec subjugavit eos.
verses.english: So they lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, and did not subdue them.

verses.latin: Nephthali quoque non delevit habitatores Bethsames, et Bethanath: et habitavit in medio Chananaei habitatoris terrae, factique sunt ei tributarii habitatores Bethsames, et Bethanath.
verses.english: Naphtali also did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-Shemesh and Beth-Anath. So they lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, and the inhabitants of Beth-Shemesh and Beth-Anath became subject to tribute to them.

verses.latin: Arctavitque Amorrhaeus filios Dan in monte: nec dedit eis locum ut ad plana descenderent.
verses.english: And the Amorites confined the sons of Dan to the mountainous region and did not allow them to come down to the plains.

verses.latin: Habitavitque Amorrhaeus in monte Hares, quod interpretatur testaceo, in Ajalon et Salabim. Et aggravata est manus domus Joseph, factusque est illi tributarius.
verses.english: And the Amorites lived in Mount Heres (which means 'clay-mountain' or 'sun-mountain'), in Aijalon, and Shaalbim. But the power of the house of Joseph was strong enough, so they became subject to tribute to them.

verses.latin: Fuit autem terminus Amorrhaei ab ascensu Scorpionis, Petra, et superiora loca.
verses.english: Now the territory of the Amorites extended from the Ascent of Akrabbim (Scorpion Pass), from Sela (Petra), and the higher places above it.

verses.latin: Post mortem Josue, consuluerunt filii Israel Dominum, dicentes: Quis ascendet ante nos contra Chananaeum, et erit dux belli?
verses.english: After Joshua died, the children of Israel asked the Lord, saying: "Who among us should go up first against the Canaanites, and lead us in this war?"

verses.latin: Et ait Dominus: Judas ascendet: ecce tradidi terram in manus ejus.
verses.english: And the Lord replied: "The tribe of Judah will go up first. Understand this: I have already given this land into their power."

verses.latin: Et dixit Judas Simeoni fratri suo: Ascende mecum in sortem meam, et pugna contra Chananaeum, ut et ego pergam tecum in sortem tuam. Et abiit cum eo Simeon.
verses.english: So the tribe of Judah said to the tribe of Simeon, their kinsman: "Come with me into the territory that was allotted to my tribe, and let us fight against the Canaanites there. In return, I will also go with you into the territory allotted to your tribe." And the tribe of Simeon went with them.

verses.latin: Ascenditque Judas, et tradidit Dominus Chananaeum et Pherezaeum in manus eorum: et percusserunt in Bezec decem millia virorum.
verses.english: So the tribe of Judah went into battle, and the Lord delivered the Canaanites and the Perizzites into their power. They struck down ten thousand men at a place called Bezek.

verses.latin: Inveneruntque Adonibezec in Bezec, et pugnaverunt contra eum, et percusserunt Chananaeum et Pherezaeum.
verses.english: They found the king of Bezek, Adonibezek, in the city of Bezek and fought against him, striking down the Canaanites and Perizzites.

verses.latin: Fugit autem Adonibezec, quem persecuti comprehenderunt, caesis summitatibus manuum ejus et pedum.
verses.english: Adonibezek fled, but they pursued and captured him. Then they cut off the thumbs of his hands and the great toes of his feet.

verses.latin: Et dixit Adonibezec: Septuaginta reges amputatis manuum ac pedum summitatibus, colligebant sub mensa mea ciborum reliquias: sicut feci, ita reddidit mihi Deus. Adduxeruntque eum in Jerusalem, et ibi mortuus est.
verses.english: Adonibezek then said: "Seventy kings, whom I had mutilated by cutting off their thumbs and great toes, used to gather the scraps from under my table. As I have done to them, so God has now done to me." They brought him to Jerusalem, and he died there.

verses.latin: Oppugnantes ergo filii Juda Jerusalem, ceperunt eam, et percusserunt in ore gladii, quicquid in ea invenerant, succensisque igni cunctis muris.
verses.english: After this, the sons of Judah attacked Jerusalem. They captured it, put everyone they found in it to the sword, and burned the entire city with fire.

verses.latin: Et post haec descenderunt ut pugnarent contra Chananaeum, qui habitabat in montanis, et in meridionalibus, et in campestribus.
verses.english: After taking Jerusalem, they went down to fight against the Canaanites who lived in the mountainous regions, the southern lands, and the plains.

verses.latin: Pergensque Judas contra Chananaeum, qui habitabat in Hebron, cujus nomen antiquitus Cariatharbe, percussit Sesai, et Ahiman, et Tholmai.
verses.english: The tribe of Judah went against the Canaanites who lived in Hebron. (Hebron was formerly called Kirjath-Arba, meaning 'the city of Arba, the father of the giants.') There, they struck down Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai—three of the Anakim, who were giants.

verses.latin: Et inde proficiscens, abiit ad habitatores Dabir, cujus nomen vetus erat Cariathsepher, id est, civitas litterarum.
verses.english: From there, they went against the inhabitants of Debir, whose old name was Kirjath-Sepher, which means "the city of books" or "the city of letters."

verses.latin: Dixitque Caleb: Qui percusserit Cariathsepher, et ceperit eam, dabo ei Axam filiam meam uxorem.
verses.english: Then Caleb said: "Whoever attacks Kirjath-Sepher and captures it, to that man I will give Achsah, my daughter, to be his wife."

verses.latin: Cumque cepisset eam Othoniel filius Cenez, frater minor Caleb, dedit ei Axam filiam suam uxorem.
verses.english: And so Othniel, the son of Kenaz (who was Caleb's younger brother, and thus Othniel's uncle), attacked and captured it. In fulfillment of his promise, Caleb gave him Achsah, his daughter, as his wife.

verses.latin: Quae cum pergeret, monuit virum suum ut peteret a patre suo agrum. Suspiravitque in asino sedens. Cui Caleb: Quid habes? inquit.
verses.english: As she was being led away to her husband, Achsah urged Othniel to ask her father for a field. Then, as she sat on her donkey, she sighed, perhaps in expectation or anxiety. Caleb asked her, "What is it you want?"

verses.latin: At illa respondit: Da mihi benedictionem, terram australem et arentem dedisti mihi: junge et irriguam. Dedit itaque ei Caleb irriguum superius, et inferius.
verses.english: But she replied: "Please give me a special gift, a blessing for my inheritance. You have given me land in the arid south. Now, please add also some watered land." So Caleb gave her both the upper and lower springs of water.

verses.latin: Filii autem Cinei cognati Moysi, ascenderunt de civitate palmarum cum filiis Juda in desertum ejus, quod est ad meridiem Arad, et habitaverunt cum eo.
verses.english: Now, the descendants of the Kenite, who were relatives of Moses (from his father-in-law Jethro's lineage), had gone up from Jericho, "the City of Palm Trees." They went with the sons of Judah into the desert region, south of Arad, and settled there among them.

verses.latin: Abiit ergo Judas cum Simeone fratre suo, et percusserunt Chananaeum qui habitabat in Sephat, et interfecerunt eum. Vocatumque est nomen urbis Horma.
verses.english: So the tribe of Judah then went with the tribe of Simeon, their kinsman, and they struck down the Canaanites who lived in Zephath. They utterly destroyed the city and its inhabitants, and the city was then called Hormah, meaning "destruction."

verses.latin: Transivitque Judas Gazar, et Ascalonem, atque Accaron, et fines earum.
verses.english: The tribe of Judah passed through Gaza, Ashkelon, and Ekron, as well as their surrounding territories. (This implies they didn't fully conquer and hold these Philistine strongholds).

verses.latin: Fuitque Dominus cum Juda, et montanos cepit: nec potuit delere habitatores vallium, quia ferratis curribus muniti erant.
verses.english: The Lord was with the tribe of Judah, and they conquered the inhabitants of the mountainous regions. However, they were unable to drive out the inhabitants of the valleys, because those people were equipped with chariots made of iron.

verses.latin: Dederuntque Caleb Hebron, sicut dixerat Moyses, qui delevit ex ea tres filios Enac.
verses.english: They gave Hebron to Caleb, just as Moses had promised, and Caleb successfully drove out from there the three sons of Anak.

verses.latin: Jebusaeum autem habitatorem Jerusalem, non deleverunt filii Benjamin, et habitavit Jebusaeus cum filiis Benjamin in Jerusalem usque in praesentem diem.
verses.english: However, the sons of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusite inhabitants of Jerusalem. So, the Jebusites continued to live alongside the sons of Benjamin in Jerusalem, right up to the time this account was written.

verses.latin: Domus quoque Joseph ascendit in Bethel, fuitque Dominus cum eis.
verses.english: The tribes descended from Joseph (Ephraim and Manasseh) also went up to attack Bethel, and the Lord was with them.

verses.latin: Nam cum explorarent urbem, quae prius Luza vocabatur,
verses.english: They sent spies to reconnoiter the city, which had previously been called Luz.

verses.latin: viderunt hominem egredientem de civitate, dixeruntque ad eum: Ostende nobis introitum civitatis, et faciemus tecum misericordiam.
verses.english: The spies saw a man leaving the city and said to him: "Show us how to enter the city, and we will show you mercy."

verses.latin: Qui cum demonstrasset eis introitum, percusserunt urbem in ore gladii: hominem autem illum, et omnem cognationem ejus, dimiserunt.
verses.english: When he showed them an entrance, they attacked the city and put all its inhabitants to the sword. But they allowed that man and his entire family to depart unharmed.

verses.latin: Qui profectus in terram Hethim, ædificavit ibi civitatem, vocavitque eam Luza: quae est nomen ejus usque in praesentem diem.
verses.english: That man went to the land of the Hittites, where he built a city and called it Luz. That has remained its name even to the present day.

verses.latin: Manasses quoque non delevit Bethsan, et Thanach cum viculis suis, et habitatores Dor, et Jeblaam, et Mageddo cum viculis suis: cœpitque Chananaeus habitare cum eis.
verses.english: But the tribe of Manasseh did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-Shan, Taanach, Dor, Ibleam, or Megiddo, nor the inhabitants of their surrounding villages. Instead, the Canaanites continued to live among them in those places.

verses.latin: Postquam autem confortatus est Israel, fecit Chananaeum tributarium, et delere noluit.
verses.english: When the people of Israel grew stronger, they indeed subjected the Canaanites to forced labor and tribute. However, they were unwilling to completely drive them out as God had commanded.

verses.latin: Ephraim quoque non interfecit Chananaeum, qui habitabat in Gazer, et habitavit Chananaeus cum eo in Gazer.
verses.english: Likewise, the tribe of Ephraim did not drive out the Canaanites who lived in Gezer, so the Canaanites continued to live alongside them in Gezer.

verses.latin: Zabulon non delevit habitatores Cetron, et Naalol: sed habitavit Chananaeus in medio ejus, factusque est ei tributarius.
verses.english: The tribe of Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron or Nahalol. Instead, the Canaanites lived among them and became forced laborers.

verses.latin: Aser quoque non delevit habitatores Achon, et Sidonis, Ahalab, et Achazib, et Helba, et Aphec, et Rohob.
verses.english: The tribe of Asher did not drive out the inhabitants of Acco, Sidon, Ahlab, Achzib, Helbah, Aphik, or Rehob.

verses.latin: Et habitavit Aser in medio Chananaei habitatoris terrae, nec delevit eum.
verses.english: So the Asherites lived among the Canaanite inhabitants of the land, failing to drive them out.

verses.latin: Nepthali quoque non delevit habitatores Bethsames, et Bethanath: et habitavit in medio Chananaei habitatoris terrae: fueruntque ei Bethsamitae et Bethanitae tributarii.
verses.english: Naphtali also did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-Shemesh or Beth-Anath. Instead, they lived among the Canaanite inhabitants of the land, and the people of Beth-Shemesh and Beth-Anath became their forced laborers.

verses.latin: Arctavitque Amorrhaeus filios Dan in monte, nec dedit eis locum ut ad plana descenderent.
verses.english: The Amorites, however, confined the sons of Dan to the mountainous regions, not allowing them to come down into the plains.

verses.latin: Habitaveruntque Amorrhaei in monte Hareg, id est, montis testacei, in Ajalon et Salabim. Aggravataque est manus domus Joseph, et facti sunt illis tributarii.
verses.english: The Amorites remained in Mount Heres (which means "Mount of Pottery"), in Aijalon, and in Shaalbim. However, the influence and power of the House of Joseph eventually grew stronger, and they forced these Amorites to become their tribute-paying laborers.

verses.latin: Et fuit terminus Amorrhaei ab ascensu Scorpionis, Sela, et ultra.
verses.english: The boundary of the Amorites extended from the Ascent of Akrabbim, continuing through Sela and beyond. (This indicates the southern extent of their power or where the Israelites contained them).

verses.latin: Ascenditque angelus Domini de Galgalis ad locum flentium, et dixit: Eduxi vos de Aegypto, et introduxi ad terram pro qua juravi patribus vestris: et pollicitus sum ut non facerem irritum pactum meum vobiscum in sempiternum:
verses.english: And the Angel of the Lord went up from Gilgal to the place of weeping, and He said: 'I led you out of Egypt and brought you into the land that I swore to give to your fathers. And I promised that I would never break My covenant with you, for all time;'

verses.latin: ita dumtaxat ut foedus non iniretis cum habitatoribus terrae hujus, sed aras eorum subverteretis: et noluistis audire vocem meam: cur hoc fecistis?
verses.english: 'provided only that you would not make a covenant with the inhabitants of this land, but instead, you were to tear down their altars. Yet you refused to obey My voice. Why did you do this?'

verses.latin: quam ob rem et ego nolui expellere eos a facie vestra: ut sint vobis in foveam, et dii eorum in offendiculum.
verses.english: Therefore, I also refused to drive them out from before you. Instead, they will be a snare to you, and their gods will become a stumbling block for you.'

verses.latin: Cumque loqueretur angelus Domini omnia verba haec ad omnes filios Israel, elevaverunt vocem suam et fleverunt.
verses.english: And when the Angel of the Lord spoke all these words to all the sons of Israel, they raised their voices and wept aloud.

verses.latin: Et vocaverunt nomen loci illius, Flentium: illicque immolaverunt Domino.
verses.english: And they called the name of that place 'The Place of Weepers', and there they offered sacrifices to the Lord.

verses.latin: Dimisit ergo Josue filios Israel, et abiit unusquisque in possessionem suam, ut occuparent eam.
verses.english: Therefore, Joshua dismissed the sons of Israel, and each man went to his own allotted land to take possession of it.

verses.latin: Et servivit populus Domino cunctis diebus Josue, et seniorum, qui longo post illum vixerant tempore, et viderant omnia opera Domini, quae fecerat Israeli.
verses.english: And the people served the Lord all the days that Joshua lived, and all the days of the elders who continued to live long after Joshua, and who had seen all the powerful works that the Lord had done for Israel.

verses.latin: Mortuus est autem Josue filius Nun, famulus Domini, centum et decem annorum:
verses.english: But Joshua, the son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died when he was one hundred and ten years old.

verses.latin: et sepelierunt eum in finibus possessionis suae in Thamnath Saraa, in monte Ephraim, a septentrionali plaga montis Gaas.
verses.english: And they buried him within the borders of his allotted territory, in Timnath-Serah, in the hill country of Ephraim, on the north side of Mount Gaash.

verses.latin: Omnisque illa generatio aggregata est ad patres suos: et alter surrexit populus post eos, qui non noverat Dominum, neque opera quae fecerat Israeli.
verses.english: And all that generation was gathered to their fathers through death. Then another people arose after them, who did not know the Lord, nor the powerful works that He had done for Israel.

verses.latin: Feceruntque filii Israel malum in conspectu Domini, et servierunt Baalim.
verses.english: And the sons of Israel did evil in the sight of the Lord, and they began to serve the Baals.

verses.latin: Et dimiserunt Dominum Deum patrum suorum, qui eduxerat eos de terra Aegypti: et secuti sunt deos alienos de diis populorum, qui habitabant in circuitu eorum, et adoraverunt eos: et ad iracundiam concitaverunt Dominum.
verses.english: And they abandoned the Lord, the God of their fathers, who had led them out of the land of Egypt. They followed after foreign gods, choosing from among the gods of the peoples who lived around them, and they worshipped these false gods. In doing so, they provoked the Lord to anger.

verses.latin: Dimiseruntque Dominum, et servierunt Baal et Astaroth.
verses.english: And they abandoned the Lord and served Baal and the Astartes.

verses.latin: Et iratus Dominus contra Israel, tradidit eos in manu diripientium, qui ceperunt eos: et vendidit ad manus hostium, qui habitabant per circuitum: nec potuerunt ultra resistere adversariis suis:
verses.english: And the Lord, being angry with Israel, handed them over to plunderers, who stole from them. He sold them into the hands of their enemies who lived around them, and they were no longer able to resist their adversaries.

verses.latin: sed quocumque pergere voluissent, super eos verteretur manus Domini, sicut locutus est, et juravit eis: et vehementer afflicti sunt.
verses.english: But wherever they wanted to go, the hand of the Lord turned against them, just as He had spoken and sworn to them. And they were greatly afflicted and suffered severely.

verses.latin: Et suscitavit Dominus judices, qui liberarent eos de manu vastatorum.
verses.english: Then the Lord raised up judges, who delivered them from the hands of their devastators.

verses.latin: Et ipsos noluerunt audire, sed fornicati sunt cum diis alienis, et adoraverunt eos. Cito deseruerunt viam, per quam ingressi fuerant patres eorum: et audientes mandata Domini, omnia fecere contraria.
verses.english: But they refused to listen even to the judges. Instead, they prostituted themselves with foreign gods and worshipped them. They quickly abandoned the way that their fathers had walked, and though they heard the commands of the Lord, they did everything contrary to them.

verses.latin: Cumque Dominus judices suscitaret, in diebus eorum flectebatur Dominus misertus pressorum et afflictionis eorum, et eorum, qui eos opprimebant.
verses.english: And when the Lord raised up judges, during the days of these judges, the Lord was moved to pity because of the groans of those who were oppressed and afflicted by their tormentors.

verses.latin: Post mortem vero judicis, rursum revertebantur, et multo majora faciebant quam fecerant patres eorum, sequentes deos alienos, servientes illis, et adorantes illos. Non dimittebant adinventiones suas, et viam duram per quam ambulare consueverant.
verses.english: But after the death of a judge, they again returned to their evil ways and did things much worse than their fathers had done, following foreign gods, serving them, and worshipping them. They did not abandon their corrupt practices, nor the stubborn path in which they had grown accustomed to walk.

verses.latin: Iratusque est furor Domini in Israel, et ait: Quia transgressa est gens ista pactum meum, quod mandavi patribus eorum, et vocem meam audire noluerunt:
verses.english: And the wrath of the Lord burned against Israel, and He said: 'Because this nation has transgressed My covenant, which I commanded their fathers, and they refused to obey My voice;'

verses.latin: et ego non auferam ultra a facie eorum gentes, quas dimisit Josue, et mori noluit:
verses.english: 'I also will no longer drive out from before them any of the nations that Joshua left remaining, not having caused them to perish completely;'

verses.latin: ut per eas probarem Israel, utrum custodiant viam Domini, et ambulent in ea, sicut custodierunt patres eorum, an non.
verses.english: 'so that through them I may test Israel, to see whether they will keep the way of the Lord and walk in it, as their fathers did, or not.'

verses.latin: Dimisit ergo Dominus omnes gentes has, et non statim expulit, nec tradidit in manum Josue.
verses.english: Therefore, the Lord allowed all these nations to remain. He did not immediately drive them out, nor did He deliver them into the hand of Joshua.

verses.latin: Ascenditque Angelus Domini de Galgalis ad locum flentium, et dixit: Ego eduxi vos de Ægypto, et introduxi in terram, pro qua juravi patribus vestris: et pollicitus sum ut non irritum facerem pactum meum vobiscum in sempiternum:
verses.english: And the Angel of the Lord came up from Gilgal to 'The Place of Weeping', and He declared: "I brought you out of Egypt and led you into the land which I swore to your fathers, and I promised that I would never make My covenant with you void forever:"

verses.latin: Ita dumtaxat ut non iniretis fœdus cum habitatoribus terræ hujus, sed aras eorum subverteretis: et noluistis audire vocem meam. Cur hoc fecistis?
verses.english: "However, you were not to make a treaty with the inhabitants of this land, but you were to tear down their altars. Yet you refused to listen to My voice. Why have you done this?"

verses.latin: Quam ob rem nolui auferre eos a facie vestra: ut sint vobis in foveam, et dii eorum in offendiculum.
verses.english: "Therefore, I also decided not to drive them out from before you, so that they would be a snare to you, and their gods would be a stumbling block to you."

verses.latin: Cumque loqueretur Angelus Domini sermones istos ad omnes filios Israël, levaverunt vocem suam, et fleverunt.
verses.english: And when the Angel of the Lord spoke these words to all the children of Israel, they raised their voices and wept aloud.

verses.latin: Et vocatum est nomen loci illius, Flentium: immolaveruntque ibi Domino.
verses.english: And the name of that place was called 'The Place of Weeping', and they offered sacrifices there to the Lord.

verses.latin: Dimisit ergo Josue populum: qui profecti sunt unusquisque in possessionem suam ut possiderent eam.
verses.english: So Joshua sent the people away, and each went to his own inheritance to take possession of it.

verses.latin: Et servierunt Domino cunctis diebus Josue, et seniorum qui longo post eum vixerunt tempore, et noverant omnia opera Domini quæ fecerat Israeli.
verses.english: And the people served the Lord all the days of Joshua, and all the days of the elders who lived for a long time after him, who had known all the works of the Lord that He had done for Israel.

verses.latin: Mortuus est autem Josue filius Nun, servus Domini, centum et decem annorum:
verses.english: Now Joshua, the son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died when he was one hundred and ten years old.

verses.latin: Et sepelierunt eum in finibus possessionis suæ in Thamnathsare, in monte Ephraim, a septentrionali plaga montis Gaas.
verses.english: And they buried him in the land of his inheritance, in Timnath-serah, in the hill country of Ephraim, north of Mount Gaash.

verses.latin: Omnisque illa generatio congregata est ad patres suos: et alter surrexit populus qui non noverat Dominum, et opera quæ fecerat Israeli.
verses.english: And all that generation was gathered to their fathers—meaning they died off—and another people arose who did not know the Lord, nor the works that He had done for Israel.

verses.latin: Feceruntque filii Israël malum in conspectu Domini, et servierunt Baalim.
verses.english: And the children of Israel did evil in the sight of the Lord, and they served the Baals—false gods.

verses.latin: Et dereliquerunt Dominum Deum patrum suorum, qui eduxerat eos de terra Ægypti, et secuti sunt deos alienos de diis populorum qui habitabant juxta illos, et adoraverunt eos: et ad iracundiam provocaverunt Dominum.
verses.english: And they abandoned the Lord, the God of their fathers, who had led them out of the land of Egypt, and they followed other gods, from among the gods of the peoples who lived around them, and they worshipped them. And they provoked the Lord to anger.

verses.latin: Dimittentes Dominum, et servientes Baal et Astaroth.
verses.english: They forsook the Lord, and served Baal and Astarte.

verses.latin: Iratusque Dominus contra Israël, tradidit eos in manus diripientium, qui diripuerunt eos: et conclusit in manibus hostium omnium per circuitum, nec potuerunt sustinere adversarios suos.
verses.english: So the Lord became angry with Israel, and He delivered them into the hands of plunderers who plundered them. He also delivered them into the hands of all their surrounding enemies, so that they could not stand against their adversaries.

verses.latin: Quocumque pergere voluissent, adversa Domini manus erat super eos, sicut locutus est, et juravit eis: et vehementer afflicti sunt.
verses.english: Wherever they wanted to go, the hand of the Lord was against them to their detriment, just as He had spoken and sworn to them. And they were greatly distressed.

verses.latin: Suscitavitque Dominus judices, qui liberarent eos de manibus vastantium.
verses.english: Nevertheless, the Lord raised up judges, who delivered them from the hands of those who devastated them.

verses.latin: Nec illos audire voluerunt, sed fornicati sunt cum diis alienis, et adoraverunt eos. Cito deseruerunt viam per quam ingressi fuerant patres eorum: et audientes mandata Domini, omnia fecere contraria.
verses.english: But they would not listen to these judges either; instead, they committed spiritual fornication with other gods and worshipped them. They quickly turned away from the path their fathers had walked, who had listened to the commandments of the Lord; they did everything contrary.

verses.latin: Cumque suscitaret Dominus judices, in diebus eorum flectebatur et propitiabatur Dominus ob afflictiones eorum, et eos qui eos opprimebant atque affligebant: non enim patiebatur, ut ultra vexarentur.
verses.english: And whenever the Lord raised up judges, in those days the Lord would relent and be moved to pity because of their groaning under those who oppressed and afflicted them. For He would not permit them to be tormented further.

verses.latin: Postquam autem mortuus esset judex, revertebantur, et multo majora faciebant quam fecerant patres eorum, sequentes deos alienos, et servientes illis, et adorantes eos. Non dimittebant adinventiones suas, et viam duram per quam ingredi consueverant.
verses.english: But after the judge died, they would turn back and act even worse than their fathers had done, following other gods, serving them, and worshipping them. They would not abandon their evil practices, nor the stubborn way they had accustomed themselves to walk.

verses.latin: Iratusque Dominus contra Israël, dixit: Quia irritam fecerunt gentem istam pactum meum, quod mandavi patribus eorum, et vocem meam audire noluerunt:
verses.english: So the Lord's anger was kindled against Israel, and He said: "Because this people has made My covenant void, which I commanded their fathers, and they have refused to listen to My voice,"

verses.latin: ego quoque non auferam ultra a facie eorum gentes, quas dimisit Josue, et mori noluit:
verses.english: "I also will no longer drive out from before them any of the nations that Joshua had left behind when he died,"

verses.latin: ut per eas tentem Israël, utrum custodiant viam Domini, et ambulent in ea, sicut custodierunt patres eorum, an non.
verses.english: "so that through them I may test Israel, to see whether they will keep the way of the Lord and walk in it, as their fathers kept it, or not."

verses.latin: Dimisit ergo Dominus omnes gentes has, et non cito expulit, nec tradidit in manus Josue.
verses.english: Therefore, the Lord allowed all these nations to remain, and He did not quickly drive them out, nor did He deliver them into the hand of Joshua.

verses.latin: Haec sunt gentes, quas Dominus dereliquit, ut in ipsis erudiret Israël, et omnes qui non noverant bella Chanaan:
verses.english: These are the nations that the Lord God allowed to remain in the land—specifically, so that through them He could train the Israelites, especially those who had not personally experienced the wars in Canaan.

verses.latin: ut saltem posteri filiorum Israël discant, et doceantur certare cum hostibus:
verses.english: God's purpose was that at least the future generations of the Israelites would learn and be taught how to fight effectively against their enemies.

verses.latin: quinque principes Philisthinorum, et omnis Chananæus, et Sidonius, atque Hevæus, qui habitabat in monte Libano, ex monte Baalhermon usque ad introitum Emath.
verses.english: These nations included: the five lords of the Philistines; all the Canaanites; the Sidonians; and the Hivites who lived in the region of Mount Lebanon, stretching from Mount Baal-hermon all the way to the entrance of Hamath.

verses.latin: Et derelicti sunt, ut in ipsis tentaretur Israël, et palam fieret utrum diligere vellent mandata Domini, quae praeceperat patribus eorum per manum Moysi, an non.
verses.english: And these nations were specifically left so that the Israelites would be tested through them. This would reveal whether they truly loved and obeyed the commandments of the Lord God, which He had given to their ancestors through Moses, or if they would disobey Him.

verses.latin: Itaque filii Israël habitaverunt in medio Chananæi, et Hethæi, et Amorrhæi, et Pherezæi, et Hevæi, et Jebusæi:
verses.english: Therefore, the sons of Israel began to live among the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.

verses.latin: acceperuntque uxores filias eorum, et filios suos dederunt filiabus eorum, et servierunt diis eorum.
verses.english: They began to take the daughters of these foreign peoples as wives, and they gave their own daughters to the sons of these peoples, and then they began to serve the gods of these nations.

verses.latin: Et fecerunt filii Israël malum in conspectu Domini, et obliti sunt Domini Dei sui, et servierunt Baalim et Astaroth.
verses.english: The sons of Israel committed evil in the sight of the Lord God. They forgot the Lord their God and began to serve the Baals and the Astartes—false gods and goddesses of the surrounding nations.

verses.latin: Irasceturque Dominus contra Israël, et tradidit eos in manu Chusan Rasathaim regis Mesopotamiæ, et servierunt ei octo annis.
verses.english: So, the Lord God's anger was kindled against Israel. He delivered them into the hand of Cushan-Rishathaim, the king of Mesopotamia. The Israelites served this king for eight years.

verses.latin: Et clamaverunt ad Dominum, qui suscitavit eis salvatorem, et liberavit eos, Othniel videlicet filium Cenez, fratrem Caleb minorem.
verses.english: Then the sons of Israel cried out to the Lord God for help. The Lord God raised up a deliverer for them who saved them—specifically, Othniel, the son of Kenaz, who was the younger brother of Caleb.

verses.latin: Et factus est super eum spiritus Domini, et judicavit Israël. Egressusque est ad pugnam, et tradidit Dominus in manu ejus Chusan Rasathaim regem Syriæ: et praevaluit super eum.
verses.english: The Spirit of the Lord God came upon Othniel, and he judged and led Israel. He went out to war, and the Lord God delivered Cushan-Rishathaim, the king of Syria, into his hand. Othniel then utterly prevailed over him.

verses.latin: Et quievit terra quadraginta annis, et obiit Othniel filius Cenez.
verses.english: After this victory, the land had peace for forty years. Then Othniel, the son of Kenaz, died.

verses.latin: Addideruntque filii Israël facere malum in conspectu Domini: qui confortavit adversum eos Eglon regem Moab, eo quod peccassent contra eum.
verses.english: But again, the sons of Israel continued to commit evil in the sight of the Lord God. Because they sinned against Him, the Lord God strengthened Eglon, the king of Moab, to be their enemy.

verses.latin: Et junxit sibi filios Ammon et Amalec: et abiit, percussitque Israël, atque possedit urbem palmarum.
verses.english: Eglon gathered the sons of Ammon and Amalek to join him. He went and attacked Israel, and they took possession of the City of Palms—Jericho.

verses.latin: Servieruntque filii Israël Eglon regi Moab decem et octo annis.
verses.english: So the sons of Israel served Eglon, the king of Moab, for eighteen years.

verses.latin: Et postea clamaverunt ad Dominum, qui suscitavit eis salvatorem vocabulo Aod, filium Gera, filii Jemini, qui utraque manu pro dextera utebatur. Mandaveruntque ei filii Israël munera Eglon regi Moab.
verses.english: And afterward, they cried out to the Lord God for help. The Lord God raised up a deliverer for them named Ehud, the son of Gera, from the tribe of Benjamin. Ehud was a left-handed man, using both hands as if they were his right. The sons of Israel sent gifts to Eglon, the king of Moab, through Ehud.

verses.latin: Qui fecit sibi gladium ancipitem habentem in medio capulum longitudinis palmi: et accinctus est eo subter vestimentum suum in femore dextro.
verses.english: Ehud had made for himself a double-edged sword, about a cubit (a Roman palm, or 7-9 inches) in length, with the hilt in the middle. He fastened it under his clothing on his right thigh—making it unusual for a right-handed guard to search for it there.

verses.latin: Obtulitque munera Eglon regi Moab. Eglon autem erat crassus nimis.
verses.english: Ehud presented the gifts to Eglon, the king of Moab. Now, King Eglon was an exceedingly fat man.

verses.latin: Cumque obtulisset munera, prosecutus est socios, qui cum eo venerant.
verses.english: After Ehud had finished presenting the gifts, he sent away the companions who had come with him.

verses.latin: Et reversus est de Galgalis, ubi erant idola, dixitque ad regem: Verbum secretum habeo ad te, o rex. Qui respondit: Silentium: et egressi sunt omnes qui circa eum erant.
verses.english: Ehud himself returned from Gilgal, where the idols were, and he said to the king, “I have a secret message for you, O King.” The king responded, “Silence!” And all who were around him then left the room.

verses.latin: Ingressus est ergo Aod ad eum, sedebat autem in æstivo cœnaculo solus: dixitque: Verbum Dei habeo ad te. Qui statim surrexit de throno.
verses.english: So Ehud went in to him. The king was sitting alone in his cool, summer upper room. Ehud then said, “I have a message from God for you.” Immediately, the king stood up from his throne.

verses.latin: Extenditque Aod manum sinistram, et abstulit gladium de femore suo dextro, infixitque in ventrem ejus tam valide,
verses.english: Then Ehud extended his left hand, drew the sword from his right thigh, and plunged it into the king's belly with such force,

verses.latin: ut capulus sequeretur ferrum in vulnere, ac peroraret in adipe. Nec extraxit gladium, sed ita omnino dereliquit. Statimque per secreta naturæ alvi proruperunt.
verses.english: that the hilt followed the blade into the wound, and the fat closed around the blade. Ehud did not pull the sword out; he left it completely embedded there. Immediately, the contents of the king's bowels came out through the wound.

verses.latin: Aod autem clausis ostiis cœnaculi, et obfirmatis, egressus est per porticum.
verses.english: Ehud then went out through the porch, having closed and locked the doors of the upper room behind him.

verses.latin: Cumque exisset, servi regis ingressi videntes clausas fores cœnaculi, dixerunt: Forsitan purgat alvum in æstivo cœnaculo.
verses.english: After he had left, the king's servants came in. Seeing the doors of the upper room closed, they said, “He is probably relieving himself in the cool, summer room.”

verses.latin: Expectantes diu usque dum erubescerent, et videntes quod nullus aperiret, tulerunt clavem: et aperientes invenerunt dominum suum jacentem in terra mortuum.
verses.english: They waited for a long time until they became embarrassed. When they saw that no one was opening the doors, they took a key, opened the doors, and found their lord lying on the floor, dead.

verses.latin: Aod autem, dum illi morarentur, effugit, et pertransivit Ad idola, locique illius ubi erant idola, evadens, venit in Seirath.
verses.english: But while they were waiting, Ehud escaped. He passed by the idols in the place where they were, evading capture, and came to Seirath.

verses.latin: Et statim cecinit buccina in monte Ephraim: et descenderunt cum eo filii Israël, ipso in fronte.
verses.english: Immediately upon his arrival, he blew a trumpet in the mountains of Ephraim. The sons of Israel descended with him, with Ehud leading the way.

verses.latin: Qui dixit eis: Sequimini me: tradidit enim Dominus inimicos nostros Moabitas in manus nostras. Descenderuntque cum eo, et occupaverunt vada Jordanis, quae trans Moab sunt: et neminem dimiserunt transire.
verses.english: He said to them, “Follow me, for the Lord God has delivered our enemies, the Moabites, into our hands!” So they went down with him and seized the fords of the Jordan River that led toward Moab, preventing anyone from crossing over.

verses.latin: Percusseruntque de Moabitis in tempore illo decem ferme millia, omnes robustos, et fortes viros: nullus eorum evadere potuit.
verses.english: At that time, they struck down about ten thousand Moabite men, all strong and valiant warriors; not one of them could escape.

verses.latin: Et humiliatus est Moab in die illo sub manu Israël: quievitque terra octoginta annis.
verses.english: So Moab was humbled on that day under the hand of Israel. And the land had peace for eighty years.

verses.latin: Post hunc fuit Samgar filius Anath, qui percussit Philisthæos sexcentos viros vomere boum: et ipse quoque liberavit Israël.
verses.english: After Ehud, there was Shamgar, the son of Anath. He struck down six hundred Philistine men with an ox-goad—a long stick with a sharp point used to drive oxen. He also delivered Israel.

verses.latin: Filii autem Israël rursum fecerunt malum in conspectu Domini, qui dereliquit eos in manu Jabin regis Chanaan, qui regnavit in Asor: habuitque ducem exercitus sui Sisaram, qui habitabat in Haroseth Gœntium.
verses.english: But the sons of Israel again committed evil in the sight of the Lord God. So the Lord God abandoned them into the hand of Jabin, the king of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor. The commander of his army was Sisera, who lived in Harosheth-Ha-goiim—meaning, 'Harosheth of the Gentiles' or 'Nations'.

verses.latin: Et clamaverunt filii Israël ad Dominum: quindecim quippe annis afflixerat eos, habebatque nongentos currus ferreos, et vehementissime oppresserat illos.
verses.english: The sons of Israel cried out to the Lord God, because Jabin had cruelly oppressed them for twenty years. He possessed nine hundred iron chariots, and he had severely afflicted the Israelites.

verses.latin: Erat autem Debora prophetis, uxor Lapidoth, quae judicabat Israël in tempore illo.
verses.english: Now, Deborah, a prophetess and the wife of Lappidoth, was judging Israel at that time.

verses.latin: Et sedebat sub palma, quae nomine illius vocabatur, inter Rama et Bethel in monte Ephraim: ascendebantque ad eam filii Israël in omne judicium.
verses.english: She used to sit under a palm tree, which was named after her, located between Ramah and Bethel in the mountains of Ephraim. The sons of Israel would come up to her for every legal judgment and dispute.

verses.latin: Misitque et vocavit Barac filium Abinoem de Cedes Nephthali: et dixit ad eum: Praecepit tibi Dominus Deus Israël: Vade, et duc exercitum in montem Thabor, et assume tecum decem millia virorum de filiis Nephthali, et de filiis Zabulon.
verses.english: Deborah sent and called for Barak, the son of Abinoam, from Kedesh-Naphtali. She said to him, “The Lord God of Israel has commanded you: Go, lead an army to Mount Tabor, and take with you ten thousand men from the sons of Naphtali and the sons of Zebulun.

verses.latin: Ego autem adducam ad te in torrente Cison Sisaram principem exercitus Jabin, et currus ejus, atque omnem multitudinem, et tradam eos in manu tua.
verses.english: I will bring Sisera, the commander of Jabin’s army, with his chariots and all his multitude, to you at the Kishon River. And I will deliver them into your hand.”

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eam Barac: Si venis mecum, veniam: si nolueris venire mecum, non veniam.
verses.english: Barak said to her, “If you come with me, I will go; but if you refuse to come with me, I will not go.”

verses.latin: Cui dixit illa: Ibo quidem tecum, sed non tua erit victoria, sed in manu mulieris Sisara tradetur. Surrexit itaque Debora, et abiit cum Barac in Cedes.
verses.english: She said to him, “I will certainly go with you. However, the victory will not be to your honor, for Sisera will be delivered into the hand of a woman.” So Deborah arose and went with Barak to Kedesh.

verses.latin: Et congregavit Barac Nephthali, et Zabulon in Cedes: ascenditque cum decem millibus pugnatorum, habens Deboram in comitatu suo.
verses.english: And Barak gathered Naphtali and Zebulun in Kedesh. He went up with ten thousand fighting men, having Deborah with him as his companion.

verses.latin: Post mortem Aod, filii Jemini, rursum fecerunt filii Israël malum in conspectu Domini.
verses.english: After Ehud, the son of Jemini, died, the sons of Israel again offended the Lord through their evil actions.

verses.latin: Tradiditque illos Dominus in manu Jabin regis Chanaan, qui regnavit in Asor: habuitque ducem exercitus sui nomine Sisara, et ipse habitabat in Haroseth Gœim.
verses.english: The Lord then allowed Jabin, king of Canaan, to conquer them. Jabin ruled from Hazor. His army's commander was Sisara, who lived in Haroseth Goim.

verses.latin: Clamaveruntque filii Israël ad Dominum: eo quod nongentos currus ferreos habuerit, et per viginti annos vehementer oppressisset eos.
verses.english: The sons of Israel cried out to the Lord for help, because King Jabin had nine hundred iron chariots and had severely oppressed them for twenty years.

verses.latin: Erat autem Debbora prophetissa, uxor Lapidoth, quæ judicabat populum in illo tempore.
verses.english: Now, during that time, a prophetess named Deborah, wife of Lapidoth, was leading the people of Israel as their judge.

verses.latin: Et sedebat sub palma, quæ nomine illius vocabatur inter Rama et Bethel in monte Ephraim: ascendebantque ad illam filii Israël in omne judicium.
verses.english: She sat under a palm tree that was named after her, located between Ramah and Bethel in the mountains of Ephraim. The sons of Israel would come up to her for every legal case and dispute.

verses.latin: Quæ misit et vocavit Barac filium Abinoem de Cedes Nephthali: dixitque ad eum: Præcepit Dominus Deus Israël: Vade, et duc exercitum in montem Thabor, tollesque tecum decem millia virorum de filiis Nephthali, et de filiis Zabulon.
verses.english: She sent a message, summoning Barak, son of Abinoam, from Kedesh-naphtali. She told him: "The Lord, the God of Israel, has given a command: 'Go and lead an army up to Mount Tabor. Take with you ten thousand men from the tribes of Naphtali and Zebulun.'"

verses.latin: Et traham ad te in torrentem Cison Sisaram principem exercitus Jabin, et currus ejus, et omnem multitudinem, tradamque eos in manu tua.
verses.english: "I will draw Sisara, the commander of Jabin's army, with his chariots and all his forces, to the Kishon Stream, to meet you there. I will then deliver them into your hands."

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eam Barac: Si venis mecum, vadam: si nolueris venire mecum, non vadam.
verses.english: Barak replied to her: "If you come with me, I will go. But if you are unwilling to come with me, then I will not go."

verses.latin: Quæ dixit illi: Ibo quidem tecum: sed in hac vice, non erit tua victoria, sed in manu mulieris tradetur Sisara. Surrexit itaque Debbora, et perrexit cum Barac in Cedes.
verses.english: She answered him: "I will certainly go with you. But on this mission, the glory of victory will not be yours, because Sisara will be delivered into the hand of a woman." So Deborah arose and went with Barak to Kedesh.

verses.latin: Qui vocatis Zabulon et Nephthali ascendit cum decem millibus pugnatorum, habuitque Debboram secum.
verses.english: Barak then called together the tribes of Zebulun and Naphtali, and he marched up with ten thousand fighters, taking Deborah with him.

verses.latin: Heber autem Cinæus recesserat quondam a ceteris Cinæis fratribus suis, filiis Hobab cognati Moysi: et tetenderat tabernacula sua juxta vallem quæ vocabatur Sennim, et erat prope Cedes.
verses.english: Now Heber the Kenite had previously separated from the other Kenites, his brothers, who were descendants of Hobab, Moses' father-in-law. Heber had pitched his tents near the valley called Sennim, which was close to Kedesh.

verses.latin: Nuntiatumque est Sisarae quod ascendisset Barac filius Abinoem in montem Thabor.
verses.english: It was reported to Sisara that Barak, son of Abinoam, had ascended Mount Tabor.

verses.latin: Statimque Sisara universos currus suos nongentos ferreos, et omnem exercitum de Haroseth Gœim ad torrentem Cison traxit.
verses.english: Immediately, Sisara gathered all his nine hundred iron chariots and his entire army from Haroseth Goim, and led them to the Kishon Stream.

verses.latin: Dixitque Debbora ad Barac: Surge, ecce dies in qua tradidit Dominus Sisaram in manu tua: ecce præit te Dominus. Descendit itaque Barac de monte Thabor, et decem millia virorum cum eo.
verses.english: Deborah then said to Barak: "Arise! This is the day in which the Lord has given Sisara into your hand. Behold, the Lord is going before you!" So Barak descended from Mount Tabor with his ten thousand men.

verses.latin: Et exterruit Dominus Sisaram, et omnes currus ejus, universamque multitudinem in ore gladii coram Barac: in tantum, ut Sisara de curru suo desiliens, pedibus fugeret.
verses.english: And the Lord threw Sisara, all his chariots, and his entire multitude into a panic before Barak's sword. The rout was so complete that Sisara leaped down from his chariot and fled on foot.

verses.latin: Barac vero persequutus est fugientes currus et exercitum usque ad Haroseth Gœim: et omnis hostium multitudo usque ad internecionem gladio cecidit.
verses.english: Barak pursued the fleeing chariots and the army all the way to Haroseth Goim. And the entire host of the enemy fell by the sword, until they were utterly destroyed.

verses.latin: Sisara autem fugiens pervenit ad tabernaculum Jahel uxoris Heber Cinæi: erat enim pax inter Jabin regem Asor, et domum Heber Cinæi.
verses.english: Sisara, however, fleeing on foot, arrived at the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite. This was because there was a peace treaty between Jabin, king of Hazor, and the house of Heber the Kenite.

verses.latin: Egressa igitur Jahel in occursum Sisarae, dixit ad eum: Intra ad me domine mi, ne timeas. Qui cum intrasset tabernaculum ejus, abscondit eum pallio.
verses.english: Jael then came out to meet Sisara and said to him: "Come in, my lord, come in to me, do not be afraid." When he had entered her tent, she covered him with a rug.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eam Sisara: Da mihi obsecro paululum aquæ ad bibendum, quia sitio. Quæ aperiens utrem lactis, dedit ei bibere, et abscondit.
verses.english: Sisara said to her: "Please give me a little water to drink, for I am thirsty." So she opened a skin of milk, gave him a drink, and covered him again.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eam Sisara: Sta ante ostium tabernaculi: et cum venerit quispiam interrogans te, et dicens: Numquid hic est aliquis? respondebis: Nullus est.
verses.english: Sisara then told her: "Stand at the entrance of the tent. If anyone comes asking you, saying: 'Is there anyone here?' you are to answer: 'There is no one.'"

verses.latin: Tulit ergo Jahel uxor Heber clavum tabernaculi, assumensque malleum, et ingressa silenter, et caute, posuit clavum super tempora ejus, et percussit maleum valide, et defixit in cerebrum ejus, graviter dormientis, atque ita mortuus est.
verses.english: So Jael, Heber's wife, took a tent peg, and taking a hammer, she quietly and cautiously went in. She placed the tent peg against his temple, and then struck the hammer forcefully, driving the peg into his brain as he slept soundly. In this way, he died.

verses.latin: Ecce autem Barac sequens Sisaram veniebat: egressaque Jahel in occursum ejus, dixit ei: Veni, et ostendam tibi virum quem quæris. Cui cum intrasset ad eam, vidit Sisaram jacentem mortuum, et clavum defixum in tempore ejus.
verses.english: And behold, Barak was coming, pursuing Sisara. Jael came out to meet him and said to him: "Come, and I will show you the man you are looking for." When he entered her tent, he saw Sisara lying dead, with the tent peg driven into his temple.

verses.latin: Humiliavit ergo Deus in die illa Jabin regem Chanaan coram filiis Israël.
verses.english: So on that day, God brought low Jabin, the king of Canaan, before the sons of Israel.

verses.latin: Qui proficiebant, et in dies singulos fortius manum suam contra Jabin regem Chanaan confirmabant, donec penitus interirent.
verses.english: And the sons of Israel continued to advance, growing stronger day by day in their resistance against Jabin, king of Canaan, until they completely destroyed him.

verses.latin: Post mortem Aod, filii Israel rursum fecerunt malum in conspectu Domini.
verses.english: After Ehud, their deliverer, had died, the people of Israel again committed sins before the Lord God.

verses.latin: Tradiditque illos Dominus in manu Iabin regis Chanaan, qui regnavit in Asor: habuitque novemcentas quadrigas ferreas, et tyrannice oppressit filios Israel viginti annis.
verses.english: So the Lord God handed them over to the power of Jabin, the king of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor. This king possessed nine hundred iron chariots, a formidable military force. He tyrannically oppressed the people of Israel for twenty years.

verses.latin: Et clamaverunt ad Dominum: siquidem crudelissime opprimebat eos viginti annis, habens novemcentas quadrigas ferreas.
verses.english: The people of Israel then cried out to the Lord God, because this king had oppressed them most cruelly for those twenty years, especially with his nine hundred iron chariots providing him such military dominance.

verses.latin: Erat autem Debbora prophetis uxor Lapidoth, quae judicabat populum in illo tempore.
verses.english: At that time, Deborah, a prophetess and the wife of Lapidoth, was exercising leadership over the people of Israel.

verses.latin: Et sedebat sub palma quae nomine illius vocabatur inter Rama et Bethel in monte Ephraim: ascendebantque ad eam filii Israel in omne judicium.
verses.english: She sat under a palm tree, which was known by her name, located between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim. The people of Israel would come to her there for every legal judgment and to receive her wisdom.

verses.latin: Quae misit et vocavit Barac filium Abinoem de Cedes Nephthali: dixitque ad eum: Praecepit Dominus Deus Israel: Vade, et duc exercitum in montem Thabor, tollesque tecum decem millia virorum de filiis Nephthali et de filiis Zabulon.
verses.english: Deborah sent for and summoned Barak, the son of Abinoam, from Kedesh-Naphtali. She said to him, 'The Lord God of Israel commands you: Go and lead an army to Mount Tabor, taking with you ten thousand men from the tribes of Naphtali and Zebulun.'

verses.latin: Et traham ad te in torrentem Cison Sisaram principem exercitus Iabin, et currus ejus, et omnem multitudinem, atque tradam eos in manu tua.
verses.english: 'And I, the Lord God, will draw Sisera, the commander of Jabin's army, along with his chariots and all his forces, to meet you at the Kishon River. Then I will deliver them into your hand, granting you victory.'

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eam Barac: Si venis mecum, vadam: si nolueris venire, non pergam.
verses.english: Barak replied to her, 'If you go with me, I will go to battle. But if you refuse to come, I will not proceed.'

verses.latin: Quae dixit ad eum: Vadam quidem tecum, sed non erit tuae gloriae victoria, quia in manu mulieris Sisara tradendus est. Surrexit itaque Debbora, et perrexit cum Barac in Cedes.
verses.english: Deborah said to him, 'I will certainly go with you. However, the glory of this victory will not be yours, because Sisera will be delivered into the hand of a woman instead.' So Deborah arose and went with Barak to Kedesh.

verses.latin: Misitque Barac ad Zabulon et Nephthali, et ascendit cum decem millibus virorum, ducentibus ei Debbora.
verses.english: Barak then sent for the men of Zebulun and Naphtali, and he marched up with ten thousand men, with Deborah personally leading them.

verses.latin: Heber autem Cineus recesserat a ceteris Cineis fratribus suis, filiis Hobab cognati Moysi: et tetenderat tabernacula sua in valle, quae vocatur Sennim et erat juxta Cedes.
verses.english: Now Heber the Kenite, whose people were descendants of Hobab, the father-in-law of Moses and traditionally allies of Israel, had separated himself from the other Kenites, his brethren. He had pitched his tents in the valley called Zaanaim, which was near Kedesh.

verses.latin: Nuntiatumque est Sisarae quod ascendisset Barac filius Abinoem in montem Thabor:
verses.english: It was reported to Sisera that Barak, the son of Abinoam, had gone up with his forces to Mount Tabor.

verses.latin: Et congregavit currus suos nongentos ferreos, et omnem exercitum de Haroseth genitum gentium ad torrentem Cison.
verses.english: So Sisera gathered all his nine hundred iron chariots and his entire army from Harosheth, a city of the Gentiles. He led them to the Kishon River.

verses.latin: Dixitque Debbora ad Barac: Surge, quia hic est dies in quo tradidit Dominus Sisaram in manu tua: en praecedit te Dominus. Descendit itaque Barac de monte Thabor, et decem millia virorum cum eo.
verses.english: Then Deborah said to Barak, 'Arise! For this is the very day on which the Lord God has delivered Sisera into your hand. Behold, the Lord God Himself goes before you in battle!' So Barak descended from Mount Tabor, and his ten thousand men with him.

verses.latin: Et perterruit Dominus Sisaram, et omnes currus ejus, universumque exercitum in ore gladii coram Barac, ita ut Sisara de curru suo desiliens, pedibus fugeret.
verses.english: And the Lord God struck terror into Sisera, his entire chariot force, and his whole army, causing them to be defeated by the edge of Barak's sword. Sisera himself, in desperation, leaped down from his chariot and fled on foot.

verses.latin: Barac autem persequens fugientes currus et exercitum usque ad Haroseth genitum gentium, omnis hostium multitudo interfecta est, absque ullo residuo.
verses.english: Barak pursued the fleeing chariots and the army all the way to Harosheth, the city of the Gentiles. The entire multitude of the enemy was slain; not a single one was left alive.

verses.latin: Sisara vero fugiens pervenit ad tabernaculum Iahel uxoris Heber Cinei: erat enim pax inter Iabin regem Asor et domum Heber Cinei.
verses.english: Sisera, still fleeing, arrived at the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite. He sought refuge there because there was a treaty of peace between Jabin, the king of Hazor, and the house of Heber the Kenite, making it seemingly a safe haven.

verses.latin: Egressa igitur Iahel in occursum Sisarae, dixit ad eum: Intra ad me domine mi, ne timeas. Qui cum intrasset ad eam in tabernaculum, cooperuit illum pallio.
verses.english: So Jael went out to meet Sisera and said to him, 'Come in, my lord, do not be afraid.' When he entered her tent, she covered him with a rug for concealment and comfort.

verses.latin: Qui dixit ad eam: Da mihi obsecro paululum aquae, quia sitio vehementer. Quae aperiens utrem lactis, dedit ei bibere, et operuit.
verses.english: He said to her, 'Please give me a little water, for I am very thirsty.' But she opened a skin of milk and gave him to drink, a gesture of great hospitality. After he drank, she covered him again.

verses.latin: Dixitque ei Sisara: Sta ante ostium tabernaculi, et cum venerit aliquis interrogans te, et dicens: Est hic aliquis? respondebis: Nullus est.
verses.english: Then Sisera instructed her, 'Stand at the entrance of the tent. If anyone comes asking you, saying, 'Is anyone here?' you must answer, 'No one is here.'

verses.latin: Iael vero uxor Heber tulit clavum tabernaculi, et tollens malleum, ingressa silenter et pariter, posuit supra tempora ejus, configens in terram: qui graviter sopore consopitus et lassitudine, mortuus est.
verses.english: But Jael, Heber's wife, took a tent peg and a hammer. She quietly and cautiously approached Sisera, who was deeply overcome by sleep and exhaustion, and placed the tent peg against his temple. She then drove the peg through his head and into the ground with the hammer, and so he died.

verses.latin: Et ecce Barac sequens Sisaram veniebat: egressaque Iahel in occursum ejus, ait illi: Veni, et ostendam tibi virum quem quaeris. Qui cum intrasset ad eam, vidit Sisaram jacentem mortuum, et clavum infixum in temporibus ejus.
verses.english: Just then, Barak arrived, pursuing Sisera. Jael went out to meet him and said, 'Come, and I will show you the man you are seeking.' So he went into her tent and saw Sisera lying dead, with the tent peg driven into his temple.

verses.latin: Humiliavit ergo Deus in die illo Iabin regem Chanaan coram filiis Israel:
verses.english: Thus, on that day, God thoroughly humbled Jabin, the king of Canaan, before the people of Israel, demonstrating His power and faithfulness.

verses.latin: Qui deinceps magis et magis apprimebat eos, donec funditus extingueretur.
verses.english: And the people of Israel, after this decisive victory, continued to press more and more upon Jabin, the king of Canaan, until he and his kingdom were utterly destroyed.

verses.latin: Cantaveruntque Debbora et Barac filius Abinoem in die illo, dicentes:
verses.english: And so, on that day, Deborah and Barak, the son of Abinoam, sang this song, saying:

verses.latin: Quod sponte obtulistis de Israel, qui non timuistis, laudate Dominum.
verses.english: For the people of Israel willingly offered themselves for battle—those who did not fear to fight—for this, praise the Lord!

verses.latin: Audite reges, percipite principes: ego ad Dominum, ego cantabo, psallam Domino Deo Israel.
verses.english: Hear this, O kings! And pay attention, O princes! I will sing to the Lord! I myself will sing praises, making melody to the Lord, the God of Israel!

verses.latin: Domine, cum exires de Seir, cum progredereris de terris Edom, terra mota est, cœlique stillaverunt aquas.
verses.english: Lord, when You marched forth from Seir, when You advanced from the lands of Edom, the earth shook, and the skies poured down their water.

verses.latin: Montes fluxerunt a facie Domini, et Sinai a facie Domini Dei Israel.
verses.english: The mountains melted away at the presence of the Lord, even Sinai itself trembled at the presence of the Lord, the God of Israel.

verses.latin: In diebus Samgar filii Anath, in diebus Jahel quieverunt semitæ: et qui ingrediebantur per eas, ambulaverunt per calles devios.
verses.english: In the days of Shamgar, son of Anath, and in the days of Jael, the main roads were deserted. Those who used to travel on them now walked through winding, secluded paths.

verses.latin: Cessaverunt fortes in Israel, et quieverunt, donec surgeret Debbora, surgeret mater in Israel.
verses.english: The strong men—the leaders—in Israel ceased to lead; they rested, until Deborah arose, until a mother arose in Israel to guide them.

verses.latin: Nova bella elegit Dominus, et portas hostium ipse subvertit: clypeus et hasta non apparuit in XL millibus Israel.
verses.english: The Lord chose new wars and personally overturned the gates of the enemies. Not a shield or a spear was seen among the forty thousand warriors of Israel.

verses.latin: Cor meum diligit principes Israel, qui sponte obtulistis vos ad periculum: benedicite Domino.
verses.english: My heart loves the leaders of Israel, who willingly risked themselves. Bless the Lord!

verses.latin: Qui ascenditis super nitentes asinos, et sedetis in judicio, et viatores in via, loquimini.
verses.english: You who ride on shining donkeys, you who sit in judgment, and you who travel along the roads—speak of these events!

verses.latin: Ubi frequentium jurgantium et vocem reddentium, ibi justitias Domini narrent, et fortitudinem in Israel: tunc descendit populus Domini ad portas.
verses.english: Where the water-drawers sing loudly, there let them recount the righteous acts of the Lord and His strength in Israel. Then the Lord's people went down to the city gates, prepared for battle.

verses.latin: Surge, surge Debbora! Surge, surge, et loquere canticum! Surge Barac, et apprehende captivos tuos, fili Abinoem!
verses.english: Arise, arise, Deborah! Arise, arise, and sing your song! Arise, Barak, and capture your captives, O son of Abinoam!

verses.latin: Factum est ergo residuum populi, deflectens ad Dominum: Descendit fortis ad me, populus Domini inter robustos.
verses.english: Then the remnant of the people turned to the Lord. The mighty leader came down to me; the Lord’s people stood among the strong.

verses.latin: Ex Ephraim de radice ejus, in Amalec, et post te Benjamin in populis tuis, de Machir principes descenderunt, et de Zabulon qui cœperunt excercitum regere.
verses.english: From Ephraim, their root, came those against Amalek; and after you, Benjamin, among your people. From Machir came down leaders, and from Zebulun came those who began to lead the army.

verses.latin: Duces Issachar cum Debbora et Barac: quomodo fusus est fortissimus, pedes ejus discurrerunt in vallem: Divisio Ruben magnæ reperta est contentionis.
verses.english: The commanders of Issachar were with Deborah and Barak. How the strongest warrior was scattered, his feet ran headlong into the valley! Among the clans of Reuben, great divisions and arguments were found.

verses.latin: Quare sedisti inter duas confabulationes, ut audires sibilus gregum? Divisio Ruben magnæ reperta est contentionis.
verses.english: Why did you sit among the sheepfolds, listening to the whistling of the flocks? Among the clans of Reuben, great divisions and arguments were found.

verses.latin: Galaad trans Jordanem quiescebat, et Dan vacabat navibus: Aser habitabat in littore maris, et in portubus morabatur.
verses.english: Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan. Dan remained by his ships. Asher dwelt by the seashore and remained in his harbors.

verses.latin: Zabulon vero et Nephthali obtulerunt animas suas ad mortem in regione Merome.
verses.english: But Zebulun and Naphtali risked their lives even unto death, on the high ground of Merom.

verses.latin: Venerunt reges, et pugnaverunt, pugnaverunt reges Chanaan in Thanach juxta aquas Mageddo, et nihil tulerunt prædæ.
verses.english: The kings came, and they fought. The kings of Canaan fought in Taanach, by the waters of Megiddo, but they carried off no plunder.

verses.latin: De cœlo pugnatum est adversum eos, stellæ manentes in ordine et cursu suo, adversum Sisaram pugnaverunt.
verses.english: From the sky, they were fought against! The stars themselves, remaining in their order and course, fought against Sisera.

verses.latin: Torrens Cison traxit cadavera eorum, torrens Cadumim, torrens Cison: conculca animam meam robustos.
verses.english: The torrent of Kishon swept away their bodies—the torrent of Cadumim, the torrent of Kishon! My soul, trample down the mighty!

verses.latin: Ungulæ equorum concitatæ sunt, fugientibus impetu fortissimis.
verses.english: The hooves of the horses beat rapidly, as the strongest warriors fled in a frenzy.

verses.latin: Maledicite terræ Meroz, dixit angelus Domini: maledicite habitatoribus ejus, quia non venerunt in auxilium Domini, in auxilium robustorum ejus.
verses.english: “Curse Meroz,” said the Angel of the Lord. “Curse its inhabitants, because they did not come to the aid of the Lord, to the aid of His strong warriors!”

verses.latin: Benedicta inter mulieres Jahel sit, uxor Haber Cinei, et benedicatur in tabernaculo suo.
verses.english: May Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, be blessed above all women, and may she be blessed within her tent.

verses.latin: Aquam petiit, et lac dedit, in phiala principum obtulit butyrum.
verses.english: He asked for water, and she gave him milk; in a noble bowl, she offered him curdled milk.

verses.latin: Sinistram manum misit ad clavum, et dextram ad fabrorum malleum, et percussit Sisaram quærens in capite locum vulneris, et configens tempora ejus.
verses.english: She reached out her left hand for a tent peg, and her right hand for a workman’s hammer. She struck Sisera, finding a vulnerable spot on his head, and pierced his temples.

verses.latin: Inter pedes ejus ruit, defecit, et mortuus est: inter pedes illius jacuit, et periit.
verses.english: Between her feet, he sank down, he collapsed, and he died. Between her feet, he lay, and he perished.

verses.latin: Per fenestram prospiciebat mater Sisara, et ululabat, et per lacrimas ejulabat: Cur moratur reverti currus ejus? quare tardaverunt pedes quadrigarum ejus?
verses.english: Through the window, Sisera's mother looked out, and wailed, lamenting through her tears: “Why is his chariot so slow to return? Why have the wheels of his chariots delayed?”

verses.latin: Unus ei sapientior de matronis respondebat, et alterius ad verba hæc illa referebat:
verses.english: One of her wise noblewomen answered her, and she herself repeated these words to the other women:

verses.latin: Forsitan nunc dividit spolia, et pulcherrima vestium variorum Sisara accipit in prædam, et monilia torquesque diversorum colorum collo ejus aptantur.
verses.english: “Perhaps he is now dividing the spoils! Sisera is taking as plunder the most beautiful and varied garments, and necklaces and richly colored jewels are being placed around his neck.”

verses.latin: Sic pereant omnes inimici tui, Domine: qui autem diligunt te, sicut sol refulgens in ortu suo, ita rutilent. Quievitque terra per quadraginta annos.
verses.english: May all Your enemies perish in this way, O Lord! But may those who love You shine like the sun when it rises in its full glory. And the land had rest for forty years.

verses.latin: Cecinit Debbora et Barac filius Abinoem in die illo dicens:
verses.english: On that day, Deborah and Barak, the son of Abinoem, sang this song, saying:

verses.latin: Quod sponte obtulistis populi ad pugnandum, benedicite Dominum.
verses.english: You, the people, offered yourselves willingly to fight. For this, bless the Lord.

verses.latin: Audite reges, percipite principes: ego sum, ego sum, quæ Domino canam, psallam Domino Deo Israël.
verses.english: Listen, you kings! Pay attention, you rulers! It is I, I myself, who will sing to the Lord; I will make music for the Lord, the God of Israel.

verses.latin: Domine, cum exires de Seir, et transires de regione Edom, terra mota est, cœli quoque stillaverunt, et nubes fluxerunt aquis.
verses.english: Lord, when you came forth from Seir, when you marched from the region of Edom, the earth shook violently. The skies also dripped, and the clouds poured down water.

verses.latin: Montes fluxerunt a facie Domini, et Sina a facie Domini Dei Israël.
verses.english: The mountains flowed, trembling before the face of the Lord. Mount Sinai itself trembled before the face of the Lord, the God of Israel.

verses.latin: In diebus Samgar filii Anath, in diebus Jahel quieverunt semitæ: et qui ingrediebantur per eas, ambulaverunt per calles detorta vestigia.
verses.english: In the days of Shamgar, the son of Anath, and in the days of Jael, the main roads were deserted. Those who used to travel on them instead walked on winding, hidden paths, avoiding the public routes.

verses.latin: Cessaverant fortes in Israël, et quieverant, donec surgeret Debbora, surgeret mater in Israël.
verses.english: The brave warriors in Israel had ceased fighting; they had rested, until Deborah rose up. She rose as a mother figure to guide Israel.

verses.latin: Nova bella elegit Dominus, et portas hostium ipse subvertit: clypeus et hasta nunquam apparuerunt in quadraginta millibus Israël.
verses.english: When new wars came, the Lord chose to fight. He Himself overthrew the gates of the enemies. But among the forty thousand warriors of Israel, no shield or spear was seen in their hands; they were unarmed.

verses.latin: Cor meum diligit principes Israël: qui sponte obtulistis vos periculo, benedicite Domino.
verses.english: My heart loves the leaders of Israel, the ones who willingly put themselves in danger. For this, bless the Lord.

verses.latin: Qui ascenditis super nitentes asinos, et sedetis in judicio, et ambulatis in via, loquimini.
verses.english: You who ride on shining donkeys, you who sit in judgment, and you who travel on the roads, speak of these events.

verses.latin: Ubi concionabantur et referebant justitias Domini, et justitias fortium ejus in Israël: tunc descendit populus Domini ad portas, et pugnavit.
verses.english: There, where they gathered to declare the righteous acts of the Lord and the just deeds of His mighty warriors in Israel, the people of the Lord then went down to the city gates and fought the enemy.

verses.latin: Surge, surge Debbora: surge, surge, et loquere canticum. Surge Barac, et apprehende captivos tuos, fili Abinoem.
verses.english: Arise, arise, Deborah! Arise, arise, and speak the song of victory! Arise, Barak, and take your captives, O son of Abinoem!

verses.latin: Tunc descendit residuum populi Dominus ad fortes: Dedit mihi Dominus principes super populum potentem.
verses.english: Then the remnant of the people of the Lord came down with the mighty ones. The Lord gave me leaders over the powerful people.

verses.latin: Ex Ephraim in Amalech, et post te de Benjamin in populos tuos, ô Amalech: de Machir principes descenderunt, et de Zabulon qui ducem faciunt.
