verses.latin: Post aliquot dies, cum jam triticum siccabatur, reversus est Samson invisere uxorem suam, afferens ei hœdum de capris: et dixit ad patrem ejus: Ingrediar ad uxorem meam in cubiculum.
verses.english: After some days had passed, when the wheat harvest was finished, Samson returned to visit his wife, bringing her a young goat. And he said to her father, “I am going to my wife in her room.”

verses.latin: Cui respondit pater ejus: Credidi quod odisses eam, et ideo dedi eam amico tuo. Habet illa sororem minorem, quæ pulchrior est ea: accipe illam pro hac.
verses.english: Her father answered him, “I truly believed that you hated her, and therefore I gave her to your friend. But look, she has a younger sister who is more beautiful than her; take her instead of your wife.”

verses.latin: Dixitque illi Samson: Absque peccato sum de Philisthiim hoc tempore: nihilominus malum eis inferam.
verses.english: Samson then said to him, “I am innocent concerning the Philistines at this time, for I will surely bring them trouble anyway.”

verses.latin: Et abiit, et capere coepit trecentas vulpes: caudasque earum junxit ad caudas, et posuit inter duas caudas tædas.
verses.english: And he went and began to catch three hundred foxes. He tied their tails together in pairs and placed a torch between each pair of tails.

verses.latin: Quas succendens igne, dimisit ad segetes Philisthiim: quibus statim exustis, et campestribus, et his quæ in vineis olivetisque seruntur, ardor exarsit.
verses.english: He lit the torches on fire, then released the foxes into the Philistines’ grain fields. The flames immediately burned up the standing grain, both in the fields and in the vineyards and olive groves, causing widespread destruction.

verses.latin: Dixeruntque Philisthiim: Quis hoc fecit? Quibus dictum est: Samson gener Thamnathæi, quia tulit uxorem ejus, et alteri tradidit. Et ascenderunt Philisthiim, et combusserunt eam, et patrem ejus.
verses.english: Then the Philistines asked, “Who did this?” And they were told, “Samson, the son-in-law of the man from Timnah, because he took his wife and gave her to another man.” So the Philistines went up and burned her and her father with fire.

verses.latin: Dixitque Samson ad eos: Quoniam fecistis hoc, per hanc ulciscar de vobis injuriam, et sic quiescam.
verses.english: Samson said to them, “Since you have done this, I will surely take revenge on you for this injustice, and then I will be satisfied.”

verses.latin: Et percussit eos ingenti plaga, ut contuderet femorum et surarum, et descendens mansit in spelunca petræ Etam.
verses.english: And he struck them down with a mighty blow, crushing them from thigh to shin. Then he went down and stayed in the cave in the rock of Etam.

verses.latin: Irgentesque Philisthiim in terra Juda, castrametati sunt in loco qui postea vocatus est Lechi, id est, Maxilla, ubi eorum exercitus congregatus est.
verses.english: Then the Philistines went up into the land of Judah and camped in a place that was later called Lehi, which means 'Jawbone,' where their army had gathered.

verses.latin: Dixeruntque ad eos tribus Juda: Quare ascendistis adversum nos? Illi responderunt: Ligare Samson venimus, et reddere eum in manus Philisthinorum, qui fecit mala nobis.
verses.english: The tribe of Judah asked them, “Why have you come up against us?” They answered, “We have come to tie up Samson and hand him over to the Philistines, for he has done evil things to us.”

verses.latin: Descenderunt ergo tria millia virorum de Juda, et de spelunca petræ Etam, vinctumque Samson tradiderunt Philisthiim.
verses.english: So three thousand men from Judah went down to the cave in the rock of Etam, where they tied Samson up and delivered him to the Philistines.

verses.latin: Qui cum ad locum Maxillæ pervenissent, occurrerunt ei Philisthiim vociferantes: et irruit Spiritus Domini in Samson, et sicut amen contritæ sunt funes quibus ligatus erat, et vincula ejus soluta ceciderunt de manibus ejus.
verses.english: When they reached the place of Lehi, the Philistines rushed to meet him, shouting. But the Spirit of the Lord powerfully came upon Samson, and the ropes that bound him became like flax threads consumed by fire, and his loosened restraints fell from his hands.

verses.latin: Invenitque maxillum asini recentem, quam tunc jacentem arripuit: et occidit in ea mille viros.
verses.english: He then found a fresh jawbone of a donkey, which was lying there at that time, and he took it up and killed a thousand men with it.

verses.latin: Et dixit: In maxilla asini, in maxilla pulli asini, delevi eos, et percussi mille viros.
verses.english: And Samson said, “With the jawbone of a donkey, with the jawbone of a young donkey, I have completely defeated them and struck down a thousand men.”

verses.latin: Cumque hæc loquens, finisset, projecit de manu sua maxillam, et appellavit nomen loci illius, Ramath Lechi, id est, Elevatio Maxillæ.
verses.english: When he had finished speaking these words, he threw the jawbone from his hand and called the name of that place Ramath Lehi, which means 'Jawbone Heights' —a memorial to his victory.

verses.latin: Sitiensque vehementer, clamavit ad Dominum, et ait: Tu dedisti in manu servi tui salutem hanc maximam: et ecce morior præ siti, et cadam in manus incircumcisorum.
verses.english: Then, being intensely thirsty, he cried out to the Lord and said, “You have granted this great deliverance into the hand of your servant. And now, behold, I am dying of thirst and will fall into the hands of the uncircumcised Philistines.”

verses.latin: Aperuit itaque Deus dentem maxillæ in loco Lechi, et egressæ sunt ex eo aquæ: bibitque, et recreavit spiritum, et vires recepit. Propter hoc appellatum est nomen fontis illius, Fons invocantis de Maxilla, usque in præsentem diem.
verses.english: So God opened a hollow place in the jawbone at Lehi, and water came out from it. Samson drank, and his spirit was revived, and he regained his strength. Because of this, the name of that spring was called En Hakkore, meaning 'Spring of Him Who Called,' and it is known by that name to this very day.

verses.latin: Et judicavit Israëlem in diebus Philisthinorum viginti annis.
verses.english: And Samson judged Israel for twenty years during the time of the Philistines’ rule.

verses.latin: Abiit itaque Samson in Gazam, et vidit ibi meretricem, ingressusque est ad eam.
verses.english: Samson then went to Gaza, and there he saw a prostitute, and he went in to her.

verses.latin: Et cum concubuissent, evaginato gladio occidit eos: et cum evaginasset gladios ut intraret, sciverunt.
verses.english: And when they had laid down, he drew his sword and killed them. And when he drew swords to enter—this phrasing is notably ambiguous in the Clementine Vulgate—they knew.

verses.latin: Abiit itaque Samson in Gazam, et vidit ibi meretricem, et ingressus est ad eam.
verses.english: Samson traveled to Gaza. While there, he saw a harlot, and he went in to be with her.

verses.latin: Et hoc cum audissent Philisthaei, et statim ad urbis portas clausissent, et custodientes tota nocte, silentio expectarent, ut evaderet mane, et occiderent eum: Samson vero dormivit usque ad medium noctis, et consurgens media nocte, apprehendit portas civitatis cum utroque poste, et vecte, imposuitque humeris suis, et asportans cuncta, posuit in vertice montis, qui respicit Hebron.
verses.english: When the Philistines heard about this, they immediately shut the city gates. They posted guards there all night, waiting silently, planning to kill Samson when he tried to escape in the morning. However, Samson slept only until the middle of the night. Rising at midnight, he seized the city gates along with both doorposts and the heavy crossbar. He hoisted the entire assembly onto his shoulders, carrying it all the way to the top of the mountain that overlooks Hebron.

verses.latin: Post haec dilexit mulierem, quae habitabat in torrente Sorec, et vocabatur Dalila.
verses.english: After these events, Samson fell in love with a woman named Delilah, who lived in the Sorek valley.

verses.latin: Veneruntque ad eam principes Philisthinorum, atque dixerunt: Decipe eum, et disce ab illo in quo sit tanta fortitudo ejus, et quomodo eum superare valeamus, et vinctum affligere: nos autem dabimus tibi singuli mille et centum argenteos.
verses.english: The Philistine lords came to Delilah and said to her, “Deceive Samson. Find out from him what makes him so incredibly strong, and how we might overcome him, so we can bind and subdue him. Each of us will give you eleven hundred pieces of silver if you succeed.”

verses.latin: Locuta est itaque Dalila ad Samson: Dic mihi, obsecro, in quo est singularis tua fortitudo, et quid te ligatum tenere poterit.
verses.english: So Delilah spoke to Samson, “Please tell me, what is the secret of your exceptional strength, and what could bind you to hold you captive?”

verses.latin: Cui Samson respondit: Si septem nervis funeis necdum siccis et tortis, ligatus fuero, efficiar infirmus, et ut ceteri homines.
verses.english: Samson answered her, “If I am bound with seven fresh, undried bowstrings that have been twisted together, I will become weak, just like any other man.”

verses.latin: Attulerunt ergo ad eam Philisthinorum principes septem funes, sicut locutus erat, necdum siccos: quibus alligavit eum.
verses.english: Then the Philistine lords brought her seven such bowstrings, still fresh as he had described, and she used them to bind him.

verses.latin: Latentes vero ad eam in cubili manebant. Et clamavit ad eum Dalila: Philisthaei super te, Samson. Qui rupit vincula, quomodo rumpitur filum de stupa, si tetigerit ignem: et non est cognitum in quo esset fortitudo ejus.
verses.english: Some Philistine men were lying in ambush in her bedroom. Delilah cried out to Samson, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” But he snapped the bonds as easily as a thread of tow breaks when it touches fire. The secret of his strength remained unknown.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eum Dalila: Ecce illusisti mihi, et mendacium locutus es: saltim nunc indica mihi in quo ligari possis.
verses.english: Delilah said to him, “See? You have mocked me and told me lies! Now, please tell me truly how you can be bound.”

verses.latin: Cui respondit Samson: Si ligatus fuero novis funibus, qui nunquam fuerunt in opere, infirmus ero, et aliorum hominum.
verses.english: Samson answered her, “If I am bound with new ropes that have never been used for any work, I will become weak, just like any other man.”

verses.latin: Ligavit ergo Dalila eum novis funibus, et clamavit: Philisthaei super te, Samson, latentibus in cubili. Et rupit iterum vincula de brachio suo, quasi fila telarum.
verses.english: So Delilah bound him with new ropes and again cried out, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” while the men lay hidden in the bedroom. But he snapped the ropes off his arms as if they were mere threads.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dalila ad Samson: Usque quo eludis me, et falsa loqueris? indica mihi quo vinci possis. Cui respondit: Si septem crines capitis mei cum licio plexueris, et clavum habenae subterfixeris in terram, dormiam, et efficiar infirmus.
verses.english: Delilah then said to Samson, “How long will you keep deceiving me and telling me lies? Tell me how you can be overcome!” He replied, “If you weave the seven braids of my head into the fabric on the loom, and then fasten it down with a peg into the ground, I will become weak and just like any other man.”

verses.latin: Quod cum fecisset Dalila, et in terra clavum defixisset, dixit ad eum: Philisthaei super te, Samson. Qui consurgens de somno, extraxit clavum cum licio et tela.
verses.english: So Delilah did this; she wove his seven braids into the fabric and fastened it with a peg to the ground. Then she cried out to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” He awoke from his sleep and pulled out the peg, along with the loom and the fabric.

verses.latin: Et dixit ad eam: Quomodo dicis quod amas me, cum animus tuus non sit mecum? tribus vicibus mentitus es mihi, et noluisti mihi dicere in quo sit tua singularis fortitudo.
verses.english: Then Delilah said to him, “How can you claim to love me when your heart isn't truly with me? You have lied to me three times, and you still refuse to tell me the secret of your extraordinary strength.”

verses.latin: Cumque molesta esset ei, et per singulos dies vocibus jugiter instaret, et quaereret, anxius usque ad mortem animus ejus est factus.
verses.english: Because she was so bothersome to him, constantly pressing him with her pleas and questions day after day, his soul became distressed to the point of death.

verses.latin: Et apertam mentem suam universam, dixit ad eam: Ferrum nunquam ascendit super caput meum, quoniam Nazaraeus, id est, consecratus Deo sum de matris utero. Si rasum fuerit caput meum, recedet a me fortitudo mea, et deficiam, et viribus evacuabor, et ero sicut ceteri homines.
verses.english: He finally revealed his whole heart to her and said, “No razor has ever touched my head, because I have been a Nazirite, consecrated to God, from my mother’s womb. If my head were shaved, my strength would depart from me, I would become weak, all my power would leave me, and I would be just like any other man.”

verses.latin: Vidensque Dalila quod sibi jam totum aperuisset animum, misit ad principes Philisthinorum, atque mandavit: Venite adhuc semel, quia jam mihi apertum est omne cor ejus. Qui ascenderunt cum pecunia, quam promiserant.
verses.english: When Delilah saw that he had fully revealed his heart to her, she sent a message to the Philistine lords, saying, “Come up once more, for he has now opened his whole heart to me.” So they came up, bringing the money they had promised.

verses.latin: At illa dormire fecit Samson super genua sua, et in sinu suo reclinare caput ejus: et advocato tonsore, rasit septem crines ejus. Et coepit eum Dalila torquere: statimque recessit ab eo fortitudo ejus.
verses.english: Delilah made Samson sleep with his head resting on her lap. Then she called for a barber and had him shave off the seven braids of Samson’s head. Delilah then began to torment him, and his strength immediately departed from him.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eum: Philisthaei super te, Samson. Et ille evigilans de somno, dixit in mente sua: Egrediar sicut ante feci, et me excutiam. Nesciebatque quod Dominus recessisset ab eo.
verses.english: She cried out to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” He woke from his sleep, thinking to himself, “I will go out as I did before and shake myself free.” But he did not know that the Lord had departed from him.

verses.latin: Apprehenderunt ergo eum Philisthaei, statimque eruerunt oculos ejus, et duxerunt Gaze, vinctumque catenis, posuerunt in carcere, et molere fecerunt.
verses.english: So the Philistines seized him. They immediately gouged out his eyes and led him down to Gaza. They bound him with bronze chains and put him in prison, making him grind grain.

verses.latin: Jam autem capilli ejus renasci coeperant.
verses.english: However, his hair had already begun to grow back.

verses.latin: Principes vero Philisthinorum congregaverunt se in unum ut immolarent hostias magnificas Dagon deo suo, et epularentur, dicentes: Tradidit deus noster in manus nostras Samson adversarium nostrum.
verses.english: The Philistine lords gathered together to offer a great sacrifice to their god Dagon and to celebrate, saying, “Our god has delivered Samson, our enemy, into our hands.”

verses.latin: Populus quoque videns, laudabat deum suum, et eadem dicebat: Tradidit deus noster in manus nostras adversarium nostrum, qui delevit terram nostram, et occidit plurimos.
verses.english: And when the people saw him, they also praised their god, saying the same thing: “Our god has delivered into our hands our enemy, who devastated our land and killed so many of us.”

verses.latin: Laetitiaque exultantes, atque animo epulantes, jusserunt vocari Samson, ut ante eos ludere: cumque de carcere esset adductus, ludebat ante illos, et stare fecerunt eum inter duas columnas.
verses.english: Overflowing with joy and feasting with great enthusiasm, they commanded that Samson be called to entertain them. When he was brought from the prison, he performed for them, and they made him stand between two pillars.

verses.latin: Dixitque Samson ad puerum ducem suum: Dimitte me, ut tangam columnas, quibus omnis sustentatur domus, et recliner super eas, et paululum requiescam.
verses.english: Then Samson said to the boy who was guiding him, “Let me feel the pillars that support this entire house, so I can lean against them and rest for a moment.”

verses.latin: Domus autem erat plena virorum ac mulierum, et omnes principes Philisthinorum aderant, et super tectum quasi tria millia virorum et mulierum spectabant ludentem Samson.
verses.english: The house was full of men and women; all the Philistine lords were present, and on the roof, about three thousand men and women were watching Samson entertain them.

verses.latin: Invocatoque Dominum, dixit: Domine Deus, memento mei, et redde mihi nunc pristinam fortitudinem, Deus meus, ut de ultione oculorum meorum simul sumam hostes meos.
verses.english: Samson then called out to the Lord, saying, “Lord God, remember me, I beg you. Strengthen me just this once more, my God, so that I may take revenge on my enemies for my two eyes.”

verses.latin: Et apprehendens ambas columnas, quibus innitebatur domus, alteramque earum dextera, et alteram laeva tenens, dixit: Moriatur anima mea cum Philisthiim.
verses.english: Then, gripping the two central pillars that supported the house, one with his right hand and the other with his left, he declared, “Let my soul die with the Philistines!”

verses.latin: Et concussis fortiter columnis, statim corruit domus, et omnes pariter, qui in ea erant, principes: et multo plures interfecit moriens, quam quos ante vivens occiderat.
verses.english: With all his might, he pushed the pillars, and immediately the house collapsed, bringing down all the lords and everyone else who was in it. So Samson killed many more people at his death than he had killed during his entire life.

verses.latin: Descendentes autem fratres ejus, et universa cognatio, tulerunt corpus ejus, et sepelierunt inter Saraa et Esthaol, in sepulchro Manue patris ejus. Judicavitque Israel viginti annis.
verses.english: Then his brothers and all his family came down, took his body, and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol, in the tomb of Manoah, his father. Samson had judged Israel for twenty years.

verses.latin: Abiit quoque Samson in Gazam, et vidit ibi mulierem meretricem, et ingressus est ad eam.
verses.english: Samson also traveled to the city of Gaza, and there he saw a harlot woman, and he went in to her.

verses.latin: Et cum audissent Philisthim, et scissent quod venisset Samson in Gazam, circumdederunt eum, et obsidebant ianuas civitatis tota nocte, tacentes et dicentes: Caudebimus eum usque mane, et tunc interficiemus.
verses.english: When the Philistines heard, and knew that Samson had come to Gaza, they surrounded him, and laid in wait by the city gates all night. They were silent, saying to themselves: "We will ambush him until morning, and then we will kill him."

verses.latin: Jacuit autem Samson usque ad medium noctis, et surgens apprehendit utrasque portæ civitatis valvas, cum postibus suis, et vecte, imposuitque humero, et asportavit ad verticem montis qui respicit Hebron.
verses.english: But Samson remained there until midnight. Then he arose, and took hold of both doors of the city gate, along with their posts and the bar, and he placed them on his shoulders and carried them to the top of the mountain that faces Hebron.

verses.latin: Post hæc dilexit mulierem, quæ habitabat in valle Sorec, et vocabulo Dalilam.
verses.english: After this, Samson fell in love with a woman who lived in the Valley of Sorek, and her name was Delilah.

verses.latin: Veneruntque ad eam principes Philisthinorum, et dixerunt: Decipe illum, et disce ab eo in quo sit robur eius tantum, et quomodo eum superare possimus, et ligatum affligere: nos autem dabimus tibi singuli mille et centum argenteos.
verses.english: The lords of the Philistines came to her and said: "Deceive him, and learn from him where his great strength lies, and how we might overcome him and bind him to afflict him. We, for our part, will each give you eleven hundred pieces of silver."

verses.latin: Locuta est ergo Dalila ad Samson: Dic mihi, obsecro, in quo sit robur tuum maximum, et quid sit quo ligatus evadere non possis.
verses.english: So Delilah said to Samson: "Tell me, I beg you, where your greatest strength lies, and what could bind you so that you could not escape."

verses.latin: Et dixit ei Samson: Si ligatus fuero septem nervis crudis, necdum siccatis, sicut chordæ novæ solent fieri, infirmabor, et ero quasi unus hominum.
verses.english: And Samson said to her: "If I am bound with seven fresh cords, not yet dried, such as new bowstrings are usually made, then I will become weak, and be like any other man."

verses.latin: Attulerunt igitur ad eam principes Philisthinorum septem funes, quasi nervos, nec dum siccos, quibus ligavit illum.
verses.english: So the lords of the Philistines brought her seven ropes, like cords, not yet dry, with which she bound him.

verses.latin: Latentibusque ad eam in cubiculo viris, clamavit: Philisthim super te, Samson. Et rupit nervos, sicut rumpitur funiculus, si tactus fuerit igne: et necdum sciebatur in quo esset robur eius.
verses.english: While men lay hidden with her in the bedroom, she cried out: "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" And he snapped the cords as a strand of flax is snapped if it touches fire. And his strength was still unknown.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dalila ad Samson: Ecce illudisti mihi, et falsum locutus es: saltem nunc dic mihi quo ligari debeas.
verses.english: Then Delilah said to Samson: "Look, you have mocked me and spoken falsely! At least now tell me how you ought to be bound."

verses.latin: Cui respondit Samson: Si ligatus fuero novis funibus, qui numquam fuerunt in opere, infirmabor, et ero quasi unus hominum.
verses.english: Samson answered her: "If I am bound with new ropes that have never been used for work, then I will become weak, and be like any other man."

verses.latin: Ligavit ergo Dalila eum novis funibus, et clamavit: Philisthim super te, Samson: latentibus ad eam in cubiculo. Et rupit illos quasi filum in manibus suis.
verses.english: So Delilah bound him with new ropes and cried out: "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" (The men were hidden with her in the bedroom.) And he snapped them like thread in his hands.

verses.latin: Et dixit Dalila ad Samson: Usque quo eludis me, et falsa loqueris? ostende mihi quo vinciaris. Cui respondit Samson: Si septem crines capitis mei cum stamine licio torquero, et clavo configero in terra, infirmabor, et ero quasi unus hominum.
verses.english: And Delilah said to Samson: "How long will you mock me and speak falsely? Show me how you can be bound!" Samson answered her: "If I weave the seven locks of my head with the warp, and fasten them with a peg into the ground, then I will become weak, and be like any other man."

verses.latin: Et Dalila pægo clavoque configit in terram. Et dixit ei: Philisthim super te, Samson! Qui consurgens de somno, extraxit clavum, et stamina licio.
verses.english: So Delilah fastened them with a peg and a nail into the ground. And she said to him: "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" But he rose from sleep, and pulled out the peg and the warp threads.

verses.latin: Et dixit ei Dalila: Quomodo dicis quod ames me, cum animus tuus non sit mecum? tribus vicibus mentitus es mihi, et noluisti mihi dicere in quo sit robur tuum maximum.
verses.english: And Delilah said to him: "How can you say that you love me, when your heart is not with me? Three times you have lied to me, and you refused to tell me where your greatest strength lies."

verses.latin: Cumque molesta esset, et per singulos dies vocibus suis eum fatigaret, et animum eius ad mortem usque tabefaceret:
verses.english: And when she became troublesome, and tormented him with her words day after day, and wore down his spirit to the point of death,

verses.latin: aperuit ei omnem animum suum, et dixit: Ferrum numquam ascendit super caput meum, quoniam Nazareus, id est, consecratus Deo sum de matris meæ utero: si rasus fuero, recedet a me fortitudo mea, et deficiam, et efficiar sicut ceteri homines.
verses.english: he opened his whole heart to her and said: "A razor has never touched my head, for I am a Nazirite, that is, consecrated to God from my mother's womb. If my head were shaven, my strength would depart from me, and I would become weak and be like any other man."

verses.latin: Vidensque Dalila quod aperuisset ei totum animum suum, misit ad principes Philisthinorum, et mandavit, dicens: Ascendite adhuc semel, quia nunc aperuit mihi totum animum suum. Illi ascenderunt, et attulerunt pecuniam secum.
verses.english: And when Delilah saw that he had opened his whole heart to her, she sent word to the lords of the Philistines and commanded them, saying: "Come up just once more, because now he has revealed his whole heart to me." So they came up, bringing the money with them.

verses.latin: Et dormire eum fecit super genua sua, et in soporem illius tondere caput eius septem cincinnis: et cœpit abigere eam, et repellere, nam inualuerat robur eius ab eo.
verses.english: And she made him sleep on her lap. While he was in a deep sleep, she had his head shaven of its seven locks. And she began to afflict him and push him away, for his strength had departed from him.

verses.latin: Et dixit: Philisthim super te, Samson! Qui concussus e somno, ait: Ibo, et excutiam me, sicut ante feci. Nesciebat autem quod Dominus recesserat ab eo.
verses.english: And she said: "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" He, roused from sleep, said: "I will go out and shake myself free, just as I have done before." But he did not know that the Lord had departed from him.

verses.latin: Apprehenderunt itaque eum Philisthim, et statim eruerunt oculos eius, et duxerunt Gazam vinctum catenis, et clausum in carcere molere fecerunt.
verses.english: So the Philistines seized him, and immediately gouged out his eyes, and led him down to Gaza, bound with chains. They put him in prison and made him grind grain.

verses.latin: Iamque capilli eius rasi denuo cœperant crescere.
verses.english: Now his shaven hair had begun to grow back again.

verses.latin: Principes autem Philisthinorum convenerunt in unum ut immolarent hostias magnificas Dagon deo suo, et epularentur, dicentes: Tradidit deus noster in manus nostras Samson inimicum nostrum.
verses.english: Now the lords of the Philistines gathered together to offer magnificent sacrifices to their god Dagon, and to feast, saying: "Our god has delivered our enemy Samson into our hands!"

verses.latin: Quod cives videntes, laudabant deum suum, eadem dicentes: Tradidit deus noster in manus nostras hostem nostrum, qui delevit terram nostram, et plurimos occidit.
verses.english: When the citizens saw this, they praised their god, saying the same things: "Our god has delivered our enemy into our hands, who devastated our land and killed many of us!"

verses.latin: Lætantibusque eis, et post cibum hilarioribus, præceperunt ut vocaretur Samson, et ludum faceret coram eis. Adduxerunt igitur eum de carcere, et ludebat in conspectu eorum: porro inter duos postes eum steterunt.
verses.english: And as they were rejoicing and became even more joyful after the meal, they commanded that Samson be called to entertain them. So they brought him from prison, and he entertained them. Then they made him stand between two pillars.

verses.latin: Et dixit ad puerum, qui ducebat eum manum: Dimitte me, ut tangam columnas quibus omnis domus nititur, et paululum requiescam.
verses.english: And he said to the boy who was leading him by the hand: "Let me go, so that I may touch the pillars on which the whole house rests, and rest a little while."

verses.latin: Domus autem erat plena virorum ac mulierum, et omnis principes Philisthinorum erant in eo loco: erant etiam in solario circiter tria millia virorum et mulierum, spectantium Samson ludere.
verses.english: Now the house was full of men and women, and all the lords of the Philistines were in that place. There were also about three thousand men and women on the roof, watching Samson entertain.

verses.latin: Invocatoque Domino, ait: Domine Deus, memento mei, et redde nunc mihi pristinam fortitudinem, Deus meus, ut ulciscar me de hostibus meis, et pro amissione oculorum meorum capiam unam ultionem.
verses.english: Then, calling upon the Lord, he said: "Lord God, remember me, and restore my former strength to me now, my God, so that I may avenge myself on my enemies, and take one vengeance for the loss of my eyes."

verses.latin: Et apprehendit Samson ambas columnas, quibus omnis nitebatur domus, alteramque earum dextera, et alteram læva, tenuit, inclinatque se, toto corpore.
verses.english: And Samson took hold of both pillars on which the whole house rested. He grasped one with his right hand and the other with his left, and he leaned with all his might.

verses.latin: Et ait: Moriatur anima mea cum Philisthim. Inclinatisque fortiter columnis, concidit domus super principes et super omnem multitudinem quæ ibi erat: multoque plures interfecit moriens, quam vivus.
verses.english: And he said: "Let my soul die with the Philistines!" Then, pushing the pillars with great force, the house collapsed upon the lords and upon all the multitude who were there. And he killed many more in his death than he had killed in his life.

verses.latin: Descendentes autem fratres eius et universa cognatio, tulerunt corpus eius, et sepelierunt inter Saraa et Esthaol, in sepulchro Manue patris eius. Judicavitque Israël viginti annis.
verses.english: Then his brothers and all his relatives went down and took his body. They buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol, in the tomb of Manoah his father. And Samson had judged Israel for twenty years.

verses.latin: Fuit ergo vir de monte Ephraim nomine Micha.
verses.english: There was a man from the mountains of Ephraim whose name was Micah.

verses.latin: Qui dixit matri suae: mille et centum argenteos quos furata es, et super quibus me execrata es audiente me, ecce ego habeo, et apud me sunt: quos reddidi tibi. Cui respondit mater: Benedicat tibi Dominus fili mi.
verses.english: He said to his mother: 'The eleven hundred pieces of silver that you stole, and about which you cursed a thief while I heard you—look, I have them. They are with me. I've given them back to you.' To which his mother replied: 'May the Lord bless you, my son.'

verses.latin: Reddidit ergo illi mille et centum argenteos: at mater ejus ait illi: Consecravi et vovi argentum hoc Domino de manu mea, ut facias ex eo sculptile et conflatile: et nunc trado tibi illud.
verses.english: So he gave back the eleven hundred pieces of silver to her. But his mother said to him: 'I have consecrated and vowed this silver to the Lord with my own hand, so that you may make an idol—both carved and cast—out of it. Now I entrust it to you.'

verses.latin: Reddidit igitur mater pecuniam filio, qui dans eam statuario, atque tabulario, fecit ex ea sculptile et conflatile: et fuit in domo Michae.
verses.english: So the mother gave the money back to her son, who then gave it to a craftsman—both a carver and a metalworker—who made from it an idol, both carved and cast. And it was placed in Micah's house.

verses.latin: Et constituit domum Michas ædiculam, id est, templum, et fecit ephod, et Theraphim, et implevit unam de filiis suis, et factus est ei sacerdos.
verses.english: Micah then set up a shrine in his house, which was like a small temple. He also made an ephod and household idols (teraphim). He consecrated one of his sons, and that son became his priest.

verses.latin: In diebus illis non erat rex in Israël, sed unusquisque quod sibi rectum videbatur hoc faciebat.
verses.english: In those days, there was no king ruling over Israel. Instead, everyone did whatever they thought was right in their own eyes.

verses.latin: Fuit quoque adolescens de Bethlehem Juda, et de cognatione ejus: eratque Levita, et peregrinus ibi.
verses.english: There was also a young man from Bethlehem in Judah, from that tribe's family line. He was a Levite, but was living there as a temporary resident.

verses.latin: Migravitque de civitate sua Bethlehem, et profectus est ut habitaret ubicumque posset, et venit cum pergeret in montem Ephraim ad domum Michae.
verses.english: He traveled away from his city of Bethlehem, and set out to live wherever he could find a place. As he was traveling through the mountains of Ephraim, he came to Micah's house.

verses.latin: Cui dixit Micha: Unde venis? Qui respondit ei: Levita sum de Bethlehem Juda, et vado ut habitem ubi potuero, et mihi congruum judicavero.
verses.english: Micah asked him: 'Where do you come from?' He answered him: 'I am a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah, and I am going to live wherever I can, and wherever seems suitable to me.'

verses.latin: Dixitque Micha: Mane apud me, et esto mihi parens, et sacerdos: et ego dabo tibi per annos singulos decem argenteos, et vestem duplicem, et cibaria. Mansitque secum.
verses.english: Micah then said: 'Stay with me, and be a father and a priest to me. And I will give you ten pieces of silver each year, two sets of garments, and your food.' So he stayed with him.

verses.latin: Et recepit eum Levita quasi filium, et habuit in pretio.
verses.english: And the Levite accepted his offer as if he were a son, and held him in high regard.

verses.latin: Implevitque ei Micha manum, et habuit adolescens Micham sacerdotem, et fuit in domo ejus.
verses.english: Micah formally consecrated the young man (as a priest), and the young man then served Micah as his priest, living in his house.

verses.latin: Et dixit Micha: Nunc scio quod benedicet mihi Dominus, eo quod habeam Levitem sacerdotem.
verses.english: And Micah said: 'Now I know that the Lord will bless me, because I have a Levite serving as priest.'

verses.latin: In diebus illis non erat rex in Israel: et tribus Dan quærebat sibi possessionem ad habitandum: non enim acceperat usque ad illum diem inter ceteras tribus sortem.
verses.english: In those days, no king ruled over the nation of Israel. The tribe of Dan was still looking for a territory to settle in and make their home, because up to that time, they had not yet received their own land among the other tribes as an inheritance.

verses.latin: Miserunt igitur filii Dan de cognatione sua quinque viros fortissimos a Saraa et Esthaol, ut explorarent terram, et diligenter investigarent: et dixerunt eis: Ite, et considerate terram. Qui cum pervenissent ad montem Ephraim, et intrassent domum Michæ, requieverunt ibi.
verses.english: So the descendants of Dan sent five of their bravest men from their kinsmen in Zorah and Eshtaol, so these men could spy out the land and investigate it thoroughly. The leaders of Dan told them, “Go and examine the land.” When these men reached the hill country of Ephraim, and entered the house of a man named Micah, they rested there for a time.

verses.latin: Et cum essent juxta domum Michæ, cognoverunt vocem adolescentis Levitas: et divertentes paulum, dixerunt ei: Unde es tu? respondit: De Bethlehem Juda sum, et Levita.
verses.english: While they were near Micah’s house, they recognized the voice of the young Levite. So, they turned aside a bit from their path and asked him, “Where are you from?” He replied, “I am from Bethlehem of Judah, and I am a Levite.”

verses.latin: Rogaveruntque eum, dicentes: Consule quæsumus Dominum, ut sciamus an prospero itinere pergimus, et an eventura sit res nostra.
verses.english: Then they asked him, saying, “Please, consult the Lord for us, so we may know if the mission we are on will be successful, and if our plans will turn out as we desire.”

verses.latin: Qui respondit eis: Ite in pace: prosperum iter faciet Dominus, et erit via vestra sub tutela.
verses.english: The Levite replied to them, “Go in peace. The Lord will make your journey prosperous, and your way will be under His protection.”

verses.latin: Perrexerunt itaque quinque viri, et venerunt Laish: videruntque populum habitantem in ea secure juxta morem Sidoniorum, otiose et absque ulla re: quia nullus erat qui vexaret eos professione cujuspiam rei, et erant procul a Sidone, neminique hominum commiscebantur.
verses.english: So the five men continued their journey and arrived at Laish. They saw the people living there securely, following the custom of the Sidonians, carefree and lacking nothing. There was no one to trouble them with any demands, and they were far from Sidon, not intermingling with any other people.

verses.latin: Reversi sunt ad fratres suos in Saraa et Esthaol, qui interrogati quid egissent, responderunt:
verses.english: When the men returned to their kinsmen in Zorah and Eshtaol, they were asked what they had done. They answered,

verses.latin: Surgite, et ascendamus ad eos: vidimus enim terram uberrimam, et spatiosam ultra modum: venite, et non sit cunctatio, ascendamus, et possideamus eam: nihil enim operis est.
verses.english: “Rise up, and let us go up against them. For we have seen a land that is very fertile and spacious beyond measure. Come, let there be no delay! Let us go up and take possession of it, for it will require no difficult work.”

verses.latin: Deus dedit nobis terram uberrimam, et latissimas possessiones.
verses.english: God has given us a very fertile land, with very wide territories for our inheritance.”

verses.latin: Veneruntque in Laish, videruntque populum habitantem in ea secure juxta morem Sidoniorum, otiose et absque ulla re: quia nullus erat qui vexaret eos professione cujuspiam rei, et erant procul a Sidone, neminique hominum commiscebantur.
verses.english: Then the five spies said, “When you go, you will come to a secure people, living in a spacious land. God has given it into your hands—a place where there is no lack of anything that is on the earth.”

verses.latin: Profecti sunt itaque de cognatione Dan, id est, de Saraa et Esthaol, sexcenti viri accincti armis militaribus.
verses.english: So, from the tribe of Dan, that is, from Zorah and Eshtaol, six hundred men set out, armed with weapons for war.

verses.latin: Ascendentesque, manserunt in Cariathiarim Juda: propter hoc et locum illum vocatus est Castrorum Dan, usque in præsentem diem: et est post tergum Cariathiarim.
verses.english: They went up and encamped in Kiriath-jearim of Judah. Because of this, that place was called Mahaneh-dan, meaning 'Camp of Dan,' until the present day. It is located behind Kiriath-jearim.

verses.latin: Inde transierunt in montem Ephraim: et cum venissent ad domum Michæ,
verses.english: From there, they passed on into the hill country of Ephraim. When they reached Micah’s house,

verses.latin: dixerunt quinque viri qui prius missi fuerant ad explorandam terram Laish, ad fratres suos: Scitis quod in domibus istis sit ephod, et theraphim, et sculptile, et conflatile? videte quid vobis placeat.
verses.english: the five men who had previously been sent to spy out the land of Laish said to their kinsmen, “Do you know that in these houses there is an ephod, and household idols, and a carved image, and a molten image? Consider what you should do.”

verses.latin: Cumque paululum divertissent, venerunt ad domum adolescentis Levitas, qui erat in domo Michæ: salutatisque eum,
verses.english: And when they had turned aside a little, they came to the house of the young Levite, who was in Micah’s house. And they greeted him.

verses.latin: et sexcenti viri, sicut erant accincti armis, steterunt ante ostium.
verses.english: Then the six hundred men, as they were armed, stood before the entrance.

verses.latin: Ascendentes autem quinque viri qui prius fuerant exploratores, ingressi sunt domum Michæ, et tulerunt ephod, et theraphim, et sculptile, et conflatile, stante sacerdote juxta ostium, et sexcentis viris, sicut erant armati, paratis ad pugnam.
verses.english: But the five men who had been the first spies went up, entered Micah’s house, and took the ephod, the household idols, the carved image, and the molten image. Meanwhile, the priest stood by the entrance, along with the six hundred armed men who were prepared for battle.

verses.latin: Intraverunt igitur, et tulerunt ephod, et theraphim, et sculptile, et conflatile. Dixitque eis sacerdos: Quid facitis?
verses.english: So, they went in and took the ephod, the household idols, the carved image, and the molten image. Then the priest said to them, “What are you doing?”

verses.latin: Qui responderunt ei: Tace, et pone digitum tuum super os tuum: veni nobiscum, et esto nobis pater et sacerdos: quid tibi melius est, aut domus unius viri sacerdos esse, aut unius tribus et cognationis in Israel?
verses.english: They replied to him, “Be silent, and put your hand over your mouth. Come with us and be a father and a priest for us. Which is better for you: to be a priest for the house of just one man, or to be a priest for a whole tribe and a family group in Israel?”

verses.latin: Gaudensque sacerdos, tulit ephod, et theraphim, et sculptile, et abiit in medio multitudinis.
verses.english: And the priest was pleased, so he took the ephod, the household idols, and the carved image, and went with the Danites, in the middle of the armed crowd.

verses.latin: Qui cum pergerent, et ante se ire facerent parvulos, et jumenta, et omnia quæ pretiosa erant,
verses.english: As they proceeded on their way, they made sure their little children, their livestock, and all their valuable possessions went ahead of them for safety.

verses.latin: jamque a domo Michæ recederent aliquantulum, et audissent qui habitabant in domo Michæ, quod raperentur fratres sui, et omnia quæ habebant,
verses.english: By the time they had moved a little distance from Micah’s house, those who lived in Micah’s house heard that their brothers, the Danites, were carrying off everything they had, along with their priest.

verses.latin: clamantes secuti sunt, et comprehendentes Micham, vehementer increpaverunt eum.
verses.english: So they cried out and pursued the Danites, and when they overtook Micah, they severely rebuked him for what had happened.

verses.latin: Qui flebili voce respondens: Deos, inquit, meos, quos mihi feci, tulistis, et sacerdotem, et omnia quæ habeo: et dicitis, Quid agis?
verses.english: Micah, responding with a tearful voice, said, “You have taken away my gods, which I made for myself, and you have taken my priest, and all that I have. And yet you ask, ‘What is wrong?’”

verses.latin: Dixeruntque ei filii Dan: Ne contende nobiscum, et ne audiat te vociferantem quisquam, ne in te irruant viri animosi, et perdas animam tuam, et omnium tuorum.
verses.english: The men of Dan said to him, “Do not argue with us, and let no one hear you crying out, lest fierce men attack you and you lose your life, and the lives of all your household.”

verses.latin: Et sic pergentes, cœperunt iter suum. Quod videns Michas, quod fortiores essent, reversus est in domum suam.
verses.english: And so, the Danites continued on their journey. When Micah saw that they were stronger than he and his men, he turned back and returned to his house.

verses.latin: Ipsi vero tulerunt quæ fecerat Michas, et sacerdotem habuerunt, et venerunt Laish ad populum quiescentem, atque securum, et percusserunt eos in ore gladii: omnemque civitatem incendio cremaverunt.
verses.english: Meanwhile, the Danites took what Micah had made, and they kept his priest. They then went to Laish, to a people who were at peace and secure. The Danites struck them down with the edge of the sword and burned the entire city with fire.

verses.latin: Nullusque eis fuit auxilio, eo quod procul habitarent a Sidone, et nulli hominum jungerentur, aut urbis aut agri. Erat autem locus in valle, quæ pertinet ad Bethrehob: ædificantesque urbem, habitaverunt in ea.
verses.english: There was no one to help them, because they lived far from Sidon and had no alliance with any other people, either of a city or of the countryside. The place was in a valley that belonged to Beth-rehob. So the Danites built a new city and lived in it.

verses.latin: Appellataque est civitas Dan, nomine patris eorum, qui fuit filius Israel, quæ prius Laish vocabatur.
verses.english: And the city was named Dan, after the name of their ancestor, who was a son of Israel. Previously, the city had been called Laish.

verses.latin: Posueruntque sibi filii Dan sculptile, et Jonathan filium Gersam filii Moysi, et filios ejus, sacerdotes in tribu Dan usque ad diem captivitatis terræ.
verses.english: And the children of Dan set up for themselves the carved image. Jonathan, the son of Gershom, the son of Moses, and his descendants became priests for the tribe of Dan, serving there until the day of the captivity of the land.

verses.latin: Mansitque apud eos idolum Michæ cunctis diebus quibus domus Dei fuit in Silo.
verses.english: So Micah’s idol remained with them for all the days that the house of God was in Shiloh.

verses.latin: Factum est igitur in diebus illis, quando non erat rex in Israel, factus est homo levites peregrinus in latere montis Ephraim, qui accepit sibi uxorem concubinam de Bethlehem Juda.
verses.english: It happened then in those days, when there was no king in Israel (which signified a time of great moral and social disorder), that a certain Levite man, a sojourner, was living on the side of Mount Ephraim. This Levite took for himself a concubine as a wife from Bethlehem of Judah.

verses.latin: Quae reliquit eum, et reversa est in domum patris sui in Bethlehem Juda, mansitque apud eum mensibus quatuor.
verses.english: She left him, and returned to her father's house in Bethlehem of Judah, and remained with him for four months.

verses.latin: Et abiit vir ejus ad eam, ut reduceret mollioribus verbis, assumens secum famulum et duos asinos: quae suscepit illum, et introduxit in domum patris sui. Quo cum vidisset socer ejus, laetatus est ob adventum illius.
verses.english: So her husband went to her, intending to bring her back by speaking kindly to her, taking with him a servant and two donkeys. She received him and brought him into her father's house. When her father-in-law saw him, he rejoiced at his arrival.

verses.latin: Et tenuit eum socer suus, et mansit apud eum tribus diebus, comedentes et bibentes, et dormientes pariter.
verses.english: And his father-in-law urged him to stay, and he remained with him for three days, eating and drinking and sleeping there together.

verses.latin: Die autem quarto, consurgens mane, voluit proficisci: dixitque ei socer ejus: Refice paululum cor tuum cibo, et sic proficisceris.
verses.english: On the fourth day, as he rose early in the morning, he intended to depart. But his father-in-law said to him: "Refresh your spirits a little with food, and then you may leave."

verses.latin: Et sederunt, et comederunt simul, et biberunt. Dixitque pater puellae ad virum suum: Oro te, commorare hic hodie, et laetare.
verses.english: So they sat and ate and drank together. And the girl's father said to her husband: "Please, stay here today and enjoy yourself."

verses.latin: Ille vero consurgens, parabat se ut abiret. Et coepit eum socer retinere, atque iterum ibi pernoctavit.
verses.english: But he rose, preparing to leave. And his father-in-law began to restrain him again, so he stayed there overnight once more.

verses.latin: Mane consurgens die quinto ut proficisceretur, dixit ei socer ejus: Refice, quaeso, cor tuum, et sustine paulisper donec transeat dies, et inclinetur ad vesperum. Et comederunt ambo.
verses.english: Rising early on the fifth day to depart, his father-in-law said to him: "Please, refresh your spirits, and wait a little while until the day passes and it declines towards evening." And they both ate together.

verses.latin: Cumque surgeret levita ut abiret cum concubina sua et famulo, dixit ei socer ejus, pater puellae: Jam tendit in occasum dies, et propinquat nox. Mane apud me hodie, et perendina: ecce sol jam declinat, pernocta hic, et laetare: et cras mane proficisceris, et venies in domum tuam.
verses.english: When the Levite rose to leave with his concubine-wife and his servant, his father-in-law, the girl's father, said to him: "Look, the day is already drawing towards its end, and night is approaching. Stay with me today and overnight. Behold, the sun is already setting; spend the night here and enjoy yourself. And tomorrow morning you may depart and go to your own house."

verses.latin: Noluit: sed statim perrexit, et venit contra Jebus, quae est Jerusalem, habens secum duos asinos onustos, et concubinam ac famulum.
verses.english: He refused. Instead, he immediately set out and came opposite Jebus, which is Jerusalem, having with him two loaded donkeys, and his concubine-wife and his servant.

verses.latin: Jamque illis propinquis Jebus, praeterierat dies multum, et irruerat caligo. Dixitque puer ad dominum suum: Veni, obsecro te, declinemus ad civitatem Jebusaeorum hanc, et maneamus in ea.
verses.english: As they were now near Jebus, a great part of the day had passed, and the twilight (the time of gathering darkness) had fallen. And the servant boy said to his master: "Please come, let us turn aside into this city of the Jebusites and stay in it."

verses.latin: Respondit ei dominus suus: Non ingrediemur oppidum gentis alienae, quae non est de Israel: sed transibimus usque Gabao.
verses.english: His master answered him: "We will not enter the town of this foreign people, who are not from Israel, but we will pass on as far as Gibeah."

verses.latin: Et addidit: Venite, pertranseamus ad unum de locis, et maneamus in Gabao, aut Rama.
verses.english: And he added: "Come, let us pass through to one of the other places, and stay in Gibeah, or in Ramah."

verses.latin: Transierunt ergo, cumque jam occumberent, sol, Gabao, quae est in tribu Benjamin, ingrediuntur.
verses.english: So they passed on, and when the sun was already setting, they entered Gibeah, which is in the tribe of Benjamin.

verses.latin: Cumque illuc intrassent, sedebant in platea civitatis, et nullus eos suscipere volebat hospitio, ut pernoctarent.
verses.english: When they had entered there, they sat in the city square, and no one was willing to receive them into their house for lodging, so that they might spend the night.

verses.latin: Et ecce apparuit homo senex, revertens de opere suo de agris vesperi, qui et ipse erat de monte Ephraim, et peregrinus habitabat in Gabaa. Erant autem viri de civitate illa filii Belial.
verses.english: And behold, an old man appeared, returning from his work in the fields in the evening. He himself was also from Mount Ephraim and was living as a sojourner in Gibeah. The men of that city, however, were sons of Belial (meaning, utterly wicked and lawless men).

verses.latin: Elevatisque oculis, vidit sedentem in platea civitatis peregrinum viatorem, et dixit ad illum: Unde venis? et quo vadis?
verses.english: And lifting his eyes, he saw the sojourning traveler sitting in the city square, and he said to him: "Where do you come from? And where are you going?"

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Proficiscimur de Bethlehem Juda usque ad latera montis Ephraim, unde et ego sum. Abiimus in Bethlehem Juda, et nunc inde revertimur, pergentes in domum meam: nullusque est qui nos domo sua suscipiat.
verses.english: He replied: "We are traveling from Bethlehem of Judah as far as the side of Mount Ephraim, from which place I also come. We went to Bethlehem of Judah, and now we are returning from there, going to my own house. And there is no one who will receive us into his house."

verses.latin: Habemus foenum et pabulum asinis nostris, et panem ac vinum in usum mei et ancillae tuae, et pueri qui est tecum: nullius rei indigemus nisi hospitio.
verses.english: "We have hay and fodder for our donkeys, and bread and wine for my use and for your female servant (my concubine-wife), and for the boy who is with you. We lack nothing except hospitality."

verses.latin: Cui dixit senex: Pax tecum sit: omne quod indigueris, de mea praebeatur industria: tantum, obsecro, ne in platea maneas.
verses.english: To him the old man said: "Peace be with you. Whatever you need shall be provided by my care. Only, please, do not remain in the square."

verses.latin: Et introduxit eum in domum suam, et pabulum asinis praebuit: et lotis pedibus eorum, acceperunt cibum.
verses.english: And he brought him into his house and provided fodder for the donkeys. After they had washed their feet, they received food.

verses.latin: Postquam refecti sunt, et laeti, ecce viri civitatis illius, filii Belial, circumdederunt domum, et fores pulsare coeperunt, clamantes ad dominum domus senem, dicentes: Educ foras hominem qui ingressus est domum tuam, ut abutamur eo.
verses.english: After they were refreshed and cheerful, behold, the men of that city, sons of Belial (wicked men), surrounded the house and began to pound on the doors, shouting to the old master of the house, saying: "Bring out the man who has come into your house, so that we may sexually abuse him."

verses.latin: Et egressus est senex ad eos, et ait: Nolite, fratres mei, nolite malum hoc facere, quia ingressus est homo in domum meam, et cessate a turpitudine hac.
verses.english: And the old man went out to them and said: "No, my brothers, do not do this evil, for this man has come into my house as my guest. And cease from this depravity."

verses.latin: Habeo filiam virginem, et hic homo uxorem concubinam: educam eas, et humiliabitis eas, et facietis eis quod vobis placuerit: tantum, obsecro, ne hanc rem sceleratam in virum hunc operemini.
verses.english: "I have a virgin daughter, and this man has his concubine-wife. I will bring them out, and you may shame them and do to them whatever pleases you. Only, I beg of you, do not commit this wicked act against this man."

verses.latin: Noluerunt audire, et vim facere conabantur homini. Quod cernens vir, apprehendit concubinam suam, et eduxit foras ad eos: quam illi abutebantur, et tota nocte inter se alternatim conculcabant, et cum jam illucesceret, dimiserunt eam.
verses.english: But they refused to listen and tried to force their way to the man. Seeing this, the man seized his concubine-wife and brought her out to them. They abused her sexually, and throughout the entire night, they violently raped her in turn. And when it was already dawning, they released her.

verses.latin: Venit mulier mane, et concidit ante januam domus, in qua hospitabatur vir ejus, ibique mortua est.
verses.english: The woman came in the morning and collapsed at the door of the house where her husband was staying, and there she died.

verses.latin: Aperiensque ostium vir mane, et egressus ut iter arriperet, invenit concubinam suam jacentem ante januam, et digitos in limine habentem.
verses.english: And her husband opened the door in the morning, and went out to set out on his journey, and found his concubine-wife lying at the door, with her hands on the threshold.

verses.latin: Et ait ad eam: Surge, et ambula. Quae nihil respondit, sed jacebat mortua. Intellegens vir cadaver esse, arripuit eam, et imposuit asino, et reversus est in domum suam.
verses.english: And he said to her: "Get up, and let's go." But she did not answer, for she lay there dead. The man, realizing it was a corpse, took her up and placed her on the donkey, and returned to his house.

verses.latin: Quo cum esset reversus, arripuit cultrum, et concubinam suam cum ossibus suis in duodecim partes, divisit, misitque in omnes fines Israel.
verses.english: When he had returned there, he took a knife, and with her bones, he divided his concubine-wife into twelve parts. And he sent these parts into all the territories of Israel.

verses.latin: Quod cum vidissent omnes, dixerunt: Nunquam factum est tale aliquid in Israel ex eo die quo ascenderunt patres nostri de terra Aegypti, usque in praesentem diem. Ponite super hoc, viri, consilium, et loquimini.
verses.english: When all who saw this saw it, they said: "Nothing like this has ever happened in Israel since the day our fathers came up out of the land of Egypt, even until the present day. Consider this, men, take counsel, and speak your minds."

verses.latin: Factum est igitur in diebus illis, judice Israel, nullus erat rex. Et erat vir quidam Levites, habitans in parte montis Ephraim, qui accepit sibi uxorem concubinam de Bethlehem Juda.
verses.english: It happened in those days, when Israel had no king and was ruled by judges, that there was a Levite man, living in the mountainous region of Ephraim. He took a concubine wife from Bethlehem in Judah.

verses.latin: Et irata est illi concubina sua, et abiit ab eo in domum patris sui in Bethlehem Juda, mansitque apud eum per quatuor menses, et eo amplius.
verses.english: His concubine became angry with him and left him, returning to her father’s house in Bethlehem in Judah. She remained there with him for four months, or even longer.

verses.latin: Surrexitque vir ejus, et abiit ad eam, ut revocaret eam, et loqueretur ei blanditiis, et duceret secum. Habebatque secum puerum et duos asinos: et suscepit eum mulier, et introduxit in domum patris sui. Quam cum vidisset socer ejus, gavisi sunt et lætati in adventu illius.
verses.english: Her husband then rose up and went to her, intending to bring her back by speaking kindly to her, and to take her with him. He had with him a servant and two donkeys. When the woman received him, she led him into her father’s house. When her father saw him, they rejoiced and celebrated his arrival.

verses.latin: Et tenuit eum socer, vir mulieris, tribus diebus, et comedit cum eo, et bibit, et mansit apud eum. Die autem quarto de nocte consurgens, voluit abire.
verses.english: The father-in-law, the woman's father, kept him for three days. During this time, the Levite ate and drank with him, and stayed at his house. On the fourth day, he rose up in the night, intending to leave.

verses.latin: Et dixit ei socer ejus: Refice paululum cor tuum, et gusta modicum panis, et sic proficisceris.
verses.english: But his father-in-law said to him, "Please, refresh your spirit a little, and taste some bread, and then you may leave."

verses.latin: Seditque et comedit, et bibit pariter utrique. Et dixit pater puellæ ad generum suum: Oro te, commorare hic hodie, et duc lætemur simul.
verses.english: So the Levite sat down, and both he and his father-in-law ate and drank together. Then the girl's father said to his son-in-law, "I beg you, stay here today, and let us enjoy ourselves together."

verses.latin: At ille cum se pararet abire mane, cogebat eum socer, dicens: Refice cor tuum, et mane hic usque ad vesperam. Et refecti sunt ambo.
verses.english: But when the Levite prepared to leave in the morning, his father-in-law urged him, saying, "Refresh your spirit, and stay here until evening." So both of them ate and drank again.

verses.latin: Surrexitque vir, ut abiret cum uxore sua et puero. Cui rursus socer: Convalesce, inquit, obsecro te, et manete hic etiam hodie: ecce sol ad occasum declinat, et jam vergente in tenebras die, mane apud me, et comede, et bibe, et cras mane cum luxerit, proficisceris, et venies in domum tuam.
verses.english: The man rose up to leave with his wife and servant. But his father-in-law again said to him, "Please, strengthen yourself, I beg you, and stay here today also. See, the sun is setting, and the day is now turning into darkness. Stay with me, eat and drink, and tomorrow morning when it becomes light, you may leave and go to your home."

verses.latin: Noluit. Sed statim perrexit, et profectus est. Venitque contra Jebus (id est, Jerusalem) et duos asinos stratos habens secum, et concubinam.
verses.english: But he refused. Instead, he immediately continued on his way and departed. He came opposite Jebus, which is Jerusalem, having with him his two saddled donkeys and his concubine.

verses.latin: Jamque advenerant juxta Jebus, et nox eminebat, et dixit puer ad dominum suum: Veni, obsecro te, declinemus ad urbem Jebusitarum, et maneamus in ea.
verses.english: Now they had approached Jebus, and night was upon them. The servant said to his master, "Please come, let us turn aside into the city of the Jebusites and stay there overnight."

verses.latin: Cui dominus respondit: Non declinabimus in urbem gentium, quæ non sunt de Israel, sed transibimus usque Gabao.
verses.english: But his master answered him, "We will not turn aside into a city of foreigners, who are not of Israel, but we will pass on to Gibeon."

verses.latin: Et addidit: Venite, properemus ad unam de civitatibus istis, et in ea manebimus, aut in Gabaa, aut in Rama.
verses.english: And he added, "Come, let us hurry to one of these cities, and we will stay there, either in Gibeah or in Ramah."

verses.latin: Transierunt igitur Jebus, et incedebant viam suam: et occubuit eis sol juxta Gabaa, quæ est in tribu Benjamin.
verses.english: So they passed by Jebus and continued on their way. The sun set for them near Gibeah, which is in the tribe of Benjamin.

verses.latin: Diverteruntque ad eam, ut manerent ibi. Cumque introissent, sederunt in platea civitatis, et nullus eos suscipiebat hospitio.
verses.english: They turned aside to Gibeah to stay there. When they had entered, they sat down in the city square, but no one offered them hospitality.

verses.latin: Et ecce vir quidam senex veniebat de opere suo et de agris vesperi, qui et ipse erat de monte Ephraim, et peregrinus habitabat in Gabaa. Homines autem regionis illius filii Belial erant, et noluerunt quemquam hospitem suscipere.
verses.english: And behold, an old man was coming from his work in the fields in the evening. He, too, was from the mountainous region of Ephraim and was living as a sojourner in Gibeah. But the men of that region were sons of Belial—meaning wicked men—and they were unwilling to receive any guest.

verses.latin: Elevatisque oculis, vidit senex virum viatorem in platea civitatis: et dixit ad eum: Unde venis? et quo vadis?
verses.english: Lifting his eyes, the old man saw the traveling man in the city square. He said to him, "Where are you coming from? And where are you going?"

verses.latin: Qui respondens ait: De Bethlehem Juda ad interiora montis Ephraim vado, unde et ego sum: et perrexi in Bethlehem Juda, et nunc revertor inde, et domum meam contendo, nullusque me in domum suam recipit.
verses.english: The man answered, "I am traveling from Bethlehem in Judah to the innermost parts of the mountainous region of Ephraim, which is where I am from. I went to Bethlehem in Judah, and now I am returning from there, striving to reach my home. Yet, no one receives me into his house."

verses.latin: Habemus paleas et fœnum in asinis nostris, et panem et vinum in usum nostrum, et ancillæ tuæ, et pueri tui: deest nobis nihil, nisi hoc unum, ut nos hospitio suscipias.
verses.english: "We have straw and fodder for our donkeys, and bread and wine for our own use, and for your female servant and your male servant. We lack nothing, except this one thing: that you take us in as guests."

verses.latin: Et dixit ei senex: Pax tecum sit: omnia quæ desideras, in promptu sunt mihi: tantum, quæso, ne in platea maneas.
verses.english: The old man said to him, "Peace be with you. All that you desire, I have at hand. Only, I beg you, do not stay in the city square."

verses.latin: Introduxitque eum in domum suam, et asinis ejus pabulum dedit: et illi, pedes suos laverunt, et comederunt, ac biberunt.
verses.english: So he brought him into his house and gave fodder to his donkeys. The travelers then washed their feet, and they ate and drank.

verses.latin: Cumque reficerentur, et in conviviis essent, ecce viri civitatis, filii Belial (id est, absque jugo) circumdederunt subito domum, et post ostium percusserunt, clamantes ad dominum domus senem, dicentes: Educ virum, qui ingressus est domum tuam, ut abutamur eo.
verses.english: While they were refreshing themselves and feasting, suddenly the men of the city, sons of Belial—meaning lawless men—surrounded the house. They struck the door, crying out to the old master of the house, saying, "Bring out the man who has entered your house, so that we may abuse him."

verses.latin: Et egressus est ad eos senex, et ait: Nolite, fratres mei, nolite, obsecro, hoc nefas facere, quia ingressus est homo in domum meam, et cessate a turpitudine hac.
verses.english: The old man went out to them and said, "No, my brothers, no, I beg you, do not commit this wickedness, because this man has entered my house. Cease from this shameful act."

verses.latin: Hanc filiam meam virginem, et illius concubinam ejiciam ad vos, ut humilietis eas, et faciatis eis quod vobis placuerit: tantum, obsecro, nolite scelus hoc operari in virum.
verses.english: "Here is my virgin daughter, and here is his concubine. I will bring them out to you, so you may humble them and do to them whatever pleases you. Only, I beg you, do not commit this wicked act against the man."

verses.latin: Nihil audientes, viri, stimulis pergebant, et volebant eum vi rapta concubina humiliari. Quod cernens vir, apprehendit concubinam suam, et de foribus ejecit. Accipientesque eam, abusi sunt ea tota nocte, et contumeliis affecerunt usque mane.
verses.english: But the men would not listen. They continued with their incitement and wanted to humiliate the man by force, having seized his concubine. Seeing this, the man took hold of his concubine and threw her out the door. They took her, abused her all night, and treated her with indignities until morning.

verses.latin: Et dimiserunt eam, abeunte die. Mulier vero mane cum jam illucesceret, venit ad ostium domus, ubi hospitabatur vir ejus, et ibi corruit.
verses.english: And they let her go as the day departed. But the woman, in the morning when it was already growing light, came to the door of the house where her husband was staying, and there she collapsed.

verses.latin: Et mortua jacebat ante pedes viri sui, qui aperiens ostium, et egressus, iter parare voluit, invenitque jacere super limen ante domum cadaver uxoris suæ, et manibus super limine expansis.
verses.english: And she lay dead before the feet of her husband. He opened the door and went out, intending to prepare for his journey. He found the corpse of his wife lying on the threshold before the house, with her hands spread out over the threshold.

verses.latin: Putans quod quiesceret, ait ad eam: Surge, et ambula. Nulla respondente, consideransque quod mortua esset, sustulit eam, et imposuit asino, reversusque est in domum suam.
verses.english: Thinking she was resting, he said to her, "Get up and walk." When no one responded, and realizing that she was dead, he lifted her up and placed her on the donkey. Then he returned to his home.

verses.latin: Quam cum esset ingressus, arripuit cultrum, et cadaver uxoris suæ cum ossibus suis in duodecim partes secuit, misitque in omnes fines Israel.
verses.english: When he had entered his house, he seized a knife and cut the corpse of his wife, along with her bones, into twelve pieces. He then sent these pieces into all the borders of Israel.

verses.latin: Cumque per singulas quasque partes hujuscemodi res ferrentur, omnis qui videbat, clamabat: Non fuit tale nec visum est, ex quo egressi sunt filii Israel de terra Ægypti usque in præsentem diem. Ponite super hoc, viri, consilium, et quod vobis videtur, loquimini.
verses.english: And as such things were carried through each and every region, everyone who saw it cried out, "Nothing like this has ever happened, nor has anything like it been seen, from the day the children of Israel came out of the land of Egypt until this present day. Men, consider this matter, consult together, and speak what seems right to you."

verses.latin: Et sicut cum una voce omnes simul dixissent: Nunquam facta est in Israel talis res, et horribilis!
verses.english: And it was as if all of them had said with one voice, "Such a terrible and horrifying thing has never happened in Israel!"
